title: Random Reed-Solomon Codes and Random Linear Codes are Locally Equivalent

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We establish an equivalence between two important random ensembles of linear codes: random linear codes (RLCs) and random Reed-Solomon (RS) codes. Specifically, we show that these models exhibit identical behavior with respect to key combinatorial properties-such as list-decodability and list-recoverability-when the alphabet size is sufficiently large.

We introduce monotone-decreasing local coordinate-wise linear (LCL) properties, a new class of properties tailored for the large alphabet regime. This class encompasses list-decodability, list-recoverability, and their average-weight variants. We develop a framework for analyzing these properties and prove a threshold theorem for RLCs: for any LCL property $\mathcal{P}$, there exists a threshold rate $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ such that RLCs are likely to satisfy $\mathcal{P}$ when $R<R_{\mathcal{P}}$ and unlikely to do so when $R>R_{\mathcal{P}}$. We extend this threshold theorem to random RS codes and show that they share the same threshold $R_{\mathcal{P}}$, thereby establishing the equivalence between the two ensembles and enabling a unified analysis of list-recoverability and related properties.

Applying our framework, we compute the threshold rate for list-decodability, proving that both random RS codes and RLCs achieve the generalized Singleton bound. This recovers a recent result of Alrabiah, Guruswami, and Li (2023) via elementary methods. Additionally, we prove an upper bound on the list-recoverability threshold and conjecture that this bound is tight. Our approach suggests a plausible pathway for proving this conjecture and thereby pinpointing the list-recoverability parameters of both models. Indeed, following the release of a prior version of this paper, Li and Shagrithaya (2025) used our equivalence theorem to show that random RS codes are near-optimally list-recoverable.

# 1 Introduction 

An (error-correcting) code of length $n$ is a set $\mathcal{C}$ of words over some fixed alphabet $\Sigma$. When $\Sigma$ is the finite field $\mathbb{F}_{q}$ (for some prime power $q$ ) and $\mathcal{C}$ is a linear subspace of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, we say that $\mathcal{C}$ is a linear code. The rate of $\mathcal{C}$ is $\frac{\log _{|\Sigma|}|C|}{n}$, which equals $\frac{\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{C}}{n}$ when $\mathcal{C}$ is linear. The distance of a linear code $\mathcal{C}$ is $\min _{x \in \mathcal{C} \backslash\{0\}} \operatorname{wt}(x)$, where $\operatorname{wt}(x)$ is the Hamming weight, which is the number of non-zero entries in $x$.

In this work, we uncover a deep connection between two of the most important random ensembles of linear codes. These ensembles are:

1. The random linear code (RLC). An RLC of length $n$ and rate $R$ is the kernel $\mathcal{C}$ of a uniformly random matrix $P \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{(n-k) \times n}$ where $k=R n .{ }^{1}$
2. The random Reed-Solomon (RS) code. A Reed-Solomon code is defined by a length $n$, a dimension $1 \leq k \leq n$, an alphabet $\mathbb{F}_{q}$, and a set of evaluation points $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$. Every codeword is the sequence of evaluations of some polynomial of degree $<k$ over the evaluation points. ${ }^{2}$ Formally, the code is

$$
\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right) ; k\right):=\left\{\left(f\left(\alpha_{1}\right), \ldots, f\left(\alpha_{n}\right)\right) \mid f \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X], \operatorname{deg} f<k\right\}
$$

When $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are sampled independently and uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}$, we say that $\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right) ; k\right)$ is a Random RS Code.

Our research is motivated by the desire to study two ubiquitous combinatorial properties of codes-list-decodability and list-recoverability. We define these notions as follows: let $\rho \in[0,1]$ and $L \in \mathbb{N}$. A code $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ is $(\rho, L)$-list-decodable if for every $z \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$,

$$
|\{x \in \mathcal{C} \mid \operatorname{wt}(x-z) \leq \rho n\}| \leq L
$$

is true. Namely, every Hamming ball of radius $\rho n$ in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ contains at most $L$ codewords. Fixing $\ell \in \mathbb{N}$, the code $\mathcal{C}$ is said to be $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable if for every list of sets $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}$, each of size at most $\ell$, there holds

$$
\left|\left\{x \in \mathcal{C} \mid\left|\left\{i \in[n] \mid x_{i} \notin Z_{i}\right\}\right| \leq \rho n\right\}\right| \leq L
$$

We note that $(\rho, L)$-list-decodability is equivalent to $(\rho, 1, L)$-list-recoverability, so the latter notion generalizes the former. All of our results mentioned in this section also apply to the average-weight versions of list-decodability and list-recoverability (see Section 2.2).

### 1.1 Our Contributions

In the first part of this work, we develop a new framework for analyzing a broad and natural family of properties, referred to as (monotone-decreasing) local coordinate-wise linear (LCL) properties. ${ }^{3}$

Using our characterization of $R_{\mathcal{P}}$, we compute the threshold rate for list-decodability (and its average-weight variant), showing that RLCs approach the generalized Singleton bound [GST22], provided that the alphabet size $q$ is at least $2^{\mathrm{O}\left(L^{2}\right)}$. The second part of this paper focuses on random RS codes. Our main result in this part is a threshold theorem for LCL properties in the random RS model. We thus say that these two code models are equivalent for LCL properties or locally equivalent.

An immediate conclusion of this equivalence is that random RS codes and RLCs share the same list-recoverability parameters. For instance, to prove that a random RS code of rate $R$ is $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable, it essentially suffices to establish the same for an RLC, and vice versa. Moreover, our characterization makes it possible to compute the relevant threshold $R_{\mathcal{P}}$, yielding results applicable to both code models simultaneously.

Prior works such as [BGM23; GZ23; AGL23] have proved that random RS codes also approach the generalized Singleton bound by using a technique first introduced in [BGM23], which made use of an equivalence between the GMS-MDS theorem and list-decoding for random RS codes. Combining the list-decodability result for RLCs from the first part of our work with the equivalence result between random RS codes and RLCs in the second part, we show that random RS codes also approach the generalized Singleton bound. This effectively recovers the main result of the prior works without relying on the GM-MDS theorem.

Our result about the local equivalence between random RS codes and RLCs, besides being interesting in its own right, provides a definite answer to the connection between the two wellstudied code models, which had been hinted at in previous works. Furthermore, our result enables researchers to establish findings regarding local properties in one code model and directly transfer them to the other, allowing them to work with their preferred code model.

Their approach proceeds by proving the bound for RLCs, after which the same result holds for random RS codes via our equivalence theorem. # 1.2 Local Code Properties and the LCL Framework 

Our notion of LCL properties extends a general framework, initially introduced in [MRRSW20], for studying list-decodability and list-recoverability as part of a broader class of code properties. A set of words in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ that all lie within the same Hamming ball of radius $\rho n$ is called $\rho$-clustered. A set of words $X \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ is said to be $(\rho, \ell)$-recovery-clustered if there exists a sequence of sets $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n} \subseteq$ $\mathbb{F}_{q}$, each of size at most $\ell$, such that for every $x \in X$, the condition $\left|\left\{i \in[n] \mid x_{i} \notin Z_{i}\right\}\right| \leq \rho n$ holds. Thus, a code $\mathcal{C}$ is $(\rho, L)$-list-decodable (or $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable) if and only if it does not contain a $\rho$-clustered (or $(\rho, \ell)$-recovery-clustered) set of size $L+1$. We interpret a clustered (or recovery-clustered) set of codewords in $\mathcal{C}$ as a witness to the code's non-list-decodability (or non-list-recoverability). This leads to the observation that list-decodability and list-recoverability have short witnesses, drawing a natural analogy to CO-NP languages or $\Pi_{1}$ logical formulas.

In [MRRSW20], this viewpoint was used to study list-decodability and list-recoverability within a newly defined class of (monotone-decreasing) local code properties. A property is said to be local if it has short witnesses, like clustered sets for list-decodability. The main finding of [MRRSW20] is that Gallagher codes, a random ensemble of LDPC codes, possess local properties similar to those of RLCs, meaning they are just as list-decodable and list-recoverable (with high probability). Later, [GM22] extended this framework to show that randomly punctured low-bias codes also share local properties with RLCs. These results can be seen as reductions between code ensembles. ${ }^{5}$

The reduction results in [MRRSW20] and [GM22] stem from the threshold theorem for local properties for RLCs [MRRSW20, Theorem 2.8]. This theorem states that for any local property $\mathcal{P}$, there is a threshold rate $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ such that RLCs with a rate below $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ are likely to satisfy $\mathcal{P}$, whereas those with a rate above $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ are unlikely to do so. An analogous theorem for plain random codes is proven in [GMRSW22].

The threshold theorem crucially relies on the property $\mathcal{P}$ having short witnesses. For instance, if $\mathcal{P}$ is the property of $(\rho, L)$-list-decodability, the witnesses are $\rho$-clustered sets of size $L+1$. To apply the theorem, subsets of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ (where $b=L+1$ ) are classified into types, and the theorem uses the expected number of these witnesses in a code $\mathcal{C}$ to determine whether $\mathcal{C}$ is likely to satisfy $\mathcal{P}$. However, the number of types grows exponentially in $q^{b}$, which is manageable for fixed $q$ but becomes unwieldy when $q$ increases with $n$. For a more formal treatment of this technique, see [MRSY24].

This exponential growth in the number of types motivates the need for a refined approach. Our framework of LCL properties avoids explicitly enumerating types and can handle cases where $q$ is large, often keeping the complexity independent of $q$ (see Remark 3.3).

Notably, random RS codes arise as random puncturings of the full RS code $\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q} ; k\right)$, which is known to have low bias, suggesting that the results of [GM22] could apply to their analysis. However, the methods developed in [MRRSW20; GM22] are tailored to codes over relatively small alphabets and do not extend to RS codes, where $q \geq n$ is required. Our LCL framework fills this gap by extending the local properties approach to the large-alphabet regime.

# 1.3 Background ${ }^{6}$
### 1.3.1 List-Decodability and List-Recoverability of RS Codes

In light of the importance of RS codes, it is a major open problem to explicitly construct RS codes with good list-decodability or list-recoverability parameters. Currently, no non-trivially listdecodable or list-recoverable explicit RS codes are known. For list-decodability, this means that known explicit RS codes are only list-decodable up to the Johnson bound ([Sud97], [GS98]). A negative list-decodability result for the full RS code $\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q} ; k\right)$ in some parameters regimes is given in [BKR09].

Lacking explicit constructions, much attention has been given to the corresponding existential problems. List-decodability of random RS codes was studied in [RW14; ST20; GLSTW21a; FKS22; GST23]. Finally, in [BGM23; GZ23; AGL23] it was shown that random RS codes are list-decodable up to capacity, ${ }^{7}$ and, furthermore, that they achieve the Elias bound ${ }^{8}$ and the generalized Singleton bound [ST20]. [BGM23] noted an interesting connection between the GM-MDS theorem (proven in [Lov21; YH19a]) and list-decoding of RS codes, which allowed them to prove that random RS code can achieve the Generalized Singleton bound, but with exponential field size. In [BDG24] the authors prove that in order to achieve the Generalized Singleton bound exactly, exponential field size is in fact necessary. However, [GZ23] circumvent this by showing that it is possible to approach the bound arbitrarily closely with only quadratic field size, which was improved to linear by the work of [AGL23]. Recent works have generalized these results to Algebraic-Geometric codes [BDGZ24], other polynomial based code ensembles [BDG23], and also to Gabidulin codes in the rank metric [GXYZ24]. We note that [BGM23; GZ23; AGL23; BDG23; BDGZ24; GXYZ24] all utilize a common framework that relies on the GM-MDS theorem, or a variant of it as a crucial component. It is not yet clear whether this framework can be extended to deal with other local properties, such as list-recovery.

# 1.3.2 List-Decodability and List-Recoverability of RLCs 

The $(\rho, L)$-list-decodability of RLCs for a fixed $L$ has been the focus of extensive research [ZP81; GHSZ02; GHK11; CGV13; Woo13; RW14; RW18; LW21; GLMRSW22; AGL23], employing at least four different methods. Collectively, these works demonstrate that RLCs achieve the Elias bound in the following settings:

- When $q=2$ [GHSZ02; LW21].
- When $q \leq O(1)$ and $\rho$ is bounded away from $\frac{q-1}{q}$ [GHK11].
- When $q \geq 2^{\Omega\left(\frac{L}{\varepsilon}\right)}$, as shown in [AGL23] and in this work.

The studies [CGV13; Woo13; RW14] provide positive results in the regime where $\rho \rightarrow \frac{q-1}{q}$, though these do not achieve the Elias bound. A significant open problem remains: proving that RLCs meet the Elias bound across all parameter settings, ideally through a unified proof technique.

The study of list-recoverability for RLCs can be divided into the large $q$ and small $q$ regimes. For large $q$ (e.g., when $q$ is exponentially large in $L$ ), the only known positive result comes from a straightforward application of the Zyablov-Pinsker Lemma [ZP81], which provides a weak lower bound on the threshold rate that rapidly diminishes as $q$ or $L$ increase. In this work, we establish the upper bound $R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq\left(1-\frac{1}{\log _{q}(L+1)}\right)\left(1-\frac{L+1}{L+1-\ell} \cdot \rho\right)$ and conjecture that this bound is tight. This is the same bound that was first proven in a recent prior work by [CZ24] for $(\rho, \ell, L)$-listrecoverability of (Folded) Reed-Solomon codes. Importantly, our result indicates that RLCs do not reach an analogue of the Elias bound for list-recovery in the large $q$ regime, meaning they are not as list-recoverable as plain random codes.

List-recovery in the regime where $\ell \geq q^{\Omega(1)}$ is studied in [RW14; RW18], which give positive results. However, [GLMRSW22] demonstrates that when $q$ is a large power of a small prime, RLCs underperform significantly compared to plain random codes in this setting as well.

# 1.4 Open Problems
### 1.4.1 List-Recovery and Non-Local Properties

Determining the threshold for list-recovery in the large $q$ regime remains a significant open problem, as it would reveal the list-recovery parameters of both random RS codes and RLCs. As noted earlier, we conjecture this threshold to be $\left(1-\frac{1}{\log _{2}(L+1)}\right)\left(1-\frac{L+1}{L+1-\ell} \cdot \rho\right)$.

Another challenge arises in the small $q$ regime, such as when $q=\operatorname{poly}(\ell)$. Our current methods cannot directly address list-recoverability in this setting due to the exponential dependence of $q$ on locality. Relaxing this dependence is an important goal, as it could deepen our understanding of list-recovery in this regime.

Furthermore, extending our framework to analyze highly non-local properties would be valuable. Consider the following example: fix a large $q$ and let $0<R<1, q^{(1-R)}<\ell<q$, and $\varepsilon>0$. Let $\mathcal{P}$ represent the property of $(0, \ell, L)$-list-recoverability for codes in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, where $L=\ell^{n} \cdot q^{-(1-R) n} \cdot(1+\varepsilon)$. Note that $\mathcal{P}$ is not a local property, since $L$ is typically exponential in $n$, but it is a natural one to consider.

Notice that $\ell^{n} \cdot q^{-(1-R) n}$ is the expected size of the set $\mathcal{C} \cap Z_{1} \times Z_{2} \times \cdots \times Z_{n}$, where $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ is a fixed code of rate $(1-R)$, and $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}$ are independent uniformly random subsets of $\mathbb{F}_{q}$ of size $\ell$. Thus, a code $\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\mathcal{P}$ if its maximum intersection with any product set $Z_{1} \times Z_{2} \times \cdots \times Z_{n}$ is at most $(1+\varepsilon)$ times this expectation. From a pseudorandomness perspective, a code satisfying $\mathcal{P}$ can be said to fool product sets (also known as combinatorial rectangles) within a $(1+\varepsilon)$ factor.

Consider the question of whether any linear code satisfies this property. In particular, do RLCs satisfy it? Both questions were essentially answered in the affirmative by [MPSW21] when $R>\frac{1}{2}$ and $q$ is a large prime. For $R \leq \frac{1}{2}$, these questions remain open. We conjecture that the answer is again positive, provided that $q$ is a sufficiently large prime.

### 1.4.2 An Alphabet-Uniform Framework

As discussed in Remark 3.3, the LCL framework developed here is well-suited for sufficiently large alphabets. For instance, Corollary 3.6 on the list-decodability of RLCs applies when $q \geq 2^{\Omega\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)}$, where $\varepsilon$ is the gap to capacity. In contrast, the classical local property framework from [MRRSW20] is designed for smaller alphabets. Our goal is to unify these approaches into a single framework that works uniformly across all alphabet sizes.

Currently, RLCs are shown to achieve the Elias bound for list-decodability in two cases: when $q$ is constant or when $q \geq 2^{\Omega\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)}$, leaving a gap between these two regimes. This gap highlights the differences between the two methods used to study local properties. The proof for the constant $q$ case [GHK11] aligns well with the classical local properties framework, whereas our proof for the large $q$ case (Corollary 3.6) is captured within the LCL framework. Developing a unified local property framework may provide a uniform proof that RLCs achieve the Elias bound across all alphabet sizes.

### 1.4.3 Optimality of Random Linear Codes

In the large $q$ regime, RLCs and random RS codes are essentially optimally list-decodable, as they approach the generalized Singleton bound. We conjecture that this optimality extends more

broadly within the class of linear codes and holds for all LCL properties (see Section 2.3 for a formal definition).

Conjecture 1.1 (Optimality of RLCs and random RS codes for LCL properties). For every $\varepsilon>0$ and $b \in \mathbb{N}$, there exist constants $n_{0}$ and $q_{0}$ such that the following holds: Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a b-local (monotone-decreasing) LCL property. If $q \geq q_{0}$ and $n \geq n_{0}$, then any linear code in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ with rate at least $R_{\mathcal{P}}+\varepsilon$ does not satisfy $\mathcal{P}$.

Following the original publication of this paper, [LS25] proved the conjecture for the case of list-recoverability. If correct, this conjecture would simultaneously generalize this negative result for list-recovery and the generalized Singleton bound.

# 2 Preliminaries
### 2.1 General Notation

We denote the set $\{1, \ldots, n\}$ by $[n]$ and let $\mathbb{F}_{q}$ be the finite field of order $q$, where $q$ is a prime power. Given a vector space $V$, the family of all linear subspaces of $V$ is denoted by $\mathcal{L}(V)$.

Given a matrix $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}(b \in \mathbb{N})$ and a code $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, we write $A \subseteq \mathcal{C}$ to mean that every column of $A$ belongs to $\mathcal{C}$. We then say that $\mathcal{C}$ contains $A$. We write $A_{i *}$ and $A_{*_{j}}$ to refer, respectively, to the $i$-th row and $j$-th column of $A$. We denote

$$
\operatorname{Dist}_{q}^{n, b}=\left\{A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b} \mid A \text { has pairwise-distinct columns }\right\}
$$

We use boldface symbols $\mathbf{0}, \mathbf{1}$ to represent the all zeroes vector and the all ones vector, respectively. If $I \subseteq[b]$, we let $\mathbf{1}_{I} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ be the indicator vector for $I$.

### 2.2 Average-Weight List-Decodability and Average-Weight List-Recoverability

As mentioned in Section 1, list-decodability and list-recoverability have average-weight variants. We define them here.

Definition 2.1. Let $X \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ be a set of words. If there exists some $z \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ such that $\frac{\sum_{z \in X} \operatorname{wt}(x-z)}{|X|} \leq$ $\rho n$, we say that $X$ is $\rho$-average-weight-clustered. If there exists a sequence of sets $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, each of size at most $\ell$, such that $\frac{\sum_{z \in X}\left|\{i \in[n] \mid x, \notin Z_{i}\}\right|}{|X|} \leq \rho n$, we say that $X$ is $(\rho, \ell)$-average-weight-recovery-clustered.

A code is said to be $(\rho, L)$-average-weight list-decodable if it does not contain a $\rho$-average-weight-clustered set of size larger than $L . \quad A$ code is said to be $(\rho, \ell, L)$-average-weight list-recoverable if it does not contain a $(\rho, \ell)$-average-weight-recovery-clustered set of size larger than $L$.

Note that the average-weight variants are stronger than the plain versions of these properties. Specifically, if a code is $(\rho, L)$-average-weight list-decodable, it is also $(\rho, L)$-list-decodable, and similarly for list-recoverability.

# 2.3 Local Coordinate-Wise Linear Properties of Codes 

A property of ( $q$-ary length $n$ ) codes is a family of codes $\mathcal{P}$ in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$. For a code $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, if $\mathcal{C} \in \mathcal{P}$, we say that $\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\mathcal{P}$.

We now define a special class of code properties called local coordinate-wise linear properties. Fix $b \in \mathbb{N}$. A sequence $\mathcal{V}=\left(\mathcal{V}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{V}_{n}\right) \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)^{n}$ is called a $b$-local profile. A matrix $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}$ is said to satisfy the profile $\mathcal{V}$ if $A_{i *} \in \mathcal{V}_{i}$ for all $1 \leq i \leq n$. We write

$$
\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}=\left\{A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b} \mid A \text { satisfies } \mathcal{V}\right\}
$$

and denote

$$
\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}=\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}} \cap \operatorname{Dist}_{q}^{n, b}
$$

A code $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ is said to contain $\mathcal{V}$ if it contains some matrix $A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}$. A property $\mathcal{P}$ of length $n$ codes is (monotone-increasing) ${ }^{9} b$-LCL ( $b$-local coordinate-wise linear) if there is a family of $b$-local profiles $\mathcal{F} \subseteq \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)^{n}$ such that

$$
\mathcal{P}=\left\{C \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \exists \mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F} \text { such that } C \text { contains } \mathcal{V}\right\}
$$

In other words, the property $\mathcal{P}$ is $b$-LCL if it consists of those codes that satisfy at least one profile from a certain family of $b$-local profiles.

The notion of $b$-local profiles can be regarded as a generalization of Intersection Matrices, originally introduced in [ST20] (see also [GZ23], which presents an equivalent concept under the name Reduced Intersection Matrices). The fundamental observation underlying these works is that any code that is not list-decodable must contain a subset of codewords that exhibit significant agreement with some fixed vector in the ambient space. Equivalently, these codewords must agree with one another on a substantial number of coordinates. [ST20] and [GZ23] leveraged this insight by representing codewords as columns of a matrix, where coordinate-wise agreements among codewords manifest as linear constraints on the matrix rows. (Reduced) Intersection Matrices serve as symbolic matrices that encode such agreement constraints. The concept of a $b$-local profile extends this framework by encoding constraints on coordinates in a more general manner, permitting the representation of linear constraints rather than merely agreement constraints. This generalization plays a crucial role in establishing the threshold theorem for RLCs and in demonstrating the equivalence between RLCs and random RS codes.

As shown by the following proposition, this framework allows us to capture natural code properties such as list-decodability and list-recoverability.

## Proposition 2.2. The following holds:

1. The complement of $(\rho, L)$-list-decodability is an $(L+1)$-LCL property with an associated $(L+1)$-local profile family of size at most $\binom{n}{\rho n}^{L+1}$.
2. The complement of $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverability is an $(L+1)$-LCL property with an associated $(L+1)$-local profile family of size at most $\binom{n}{\rho n}^{L+1} \cdot \ell^{(L+1) n}$.

# 3 Organization and Formal Statements of Main Results 

Having defined the notion of LCL properties, we turn to formally state our main results.

### 3.1 Results for Random Linear Codes

In Section 4 we study LCL properties of RLCs, and prove the threshold theorem for RLCs.
Theorem 3.1 (RLC thresholds for LCL properties over a large alphabet). Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a b-LCL property of codes in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ and let $\mathcal{F} \subseteq \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)^{n}$ be a corresponding family of profiles. Let $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ be an RLC of rate $R$. Then, there is some threshold rate $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ for which the following holds.

1. If $R \geq R_{\mathcal{P}}+\varepsilon$ then $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\mathcal{P}] \geq 1-q^{-\varepsilon n+b^{2}}$.
2. If $R \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}-\varepsilon$ then $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\mathcal{P}] \leq|\mathcal{F}| \cdot q^{-\varepsilon n+b^{2}}$.

3. In particular, if $R \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}-\varepsilon$ and $q \geq 2^{\frac{2 \log q|\mathcal{F}|}{\varepsilon n}}$ then $\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C}\right.$ satisfies $\left.\mathcal{P}\right] \leq q^{-\frac{\varepsilon n}{2}+b^{2}}$.

Remark 3.2 (Characterization of $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ ). The usefulness of Theorem 3.1 depends on having a clear characterization of $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ in terms of certain first-moment terms. Such a characterization is developed and given explicitly in Eq. (14) in Section 4.

Remark 3.3 (The alphabet size and "reasonable" properties). As demonstrated by the second and third parts of Theorem 3.1, the usefulness of the theorem hinges on $\mathcal{F}$ not being too large in terms of $q$. For the probability bound to be meaningful, we need

$$
q \geq|\mathcal{F}|^{\Omega\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)}
$$

at the very least. It seems that many natural LCL properties have $|\mathcal{F}| \geq 2^{\Omega(n)}$ at the very least, making $q \geq 2^{\Omega\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)}$ a minimum requirement.

Informally, we define a property $\mathcal{P}$ as reasonable if its associated set of local profiles satisfies

$$
|\mathcal{F}| \leq q^{a_{q \rightarrow \infty}(n)}
$$

Note that only a reasonable property can satisfy Eq. (1). Fortunately, the complements of listrecoverability and list-decodability with fixed list-size are reasonable (Proposition 2.2).

Furthermore, let $\mathcal{P}$ denote a b-LCL property and let $M=\left\{\mathcal{V}_{i} \mid \mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}\right\}$, the set of all linear subspaces of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ that can appear in a profile in $\mathcal{F}$. It is not hard to see that $|\mathcal{F}| \leq|M|^{n}$. Hence, as long as $|M|$ depends only on $b$ but not on $q$, the property $\mathcal{P}$ is reasonable.

For example, suppose that $\mathcal{P}$ is the property of not being $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable. As demonstrated in the proof of Proposition 2.2, each element of $M$ is defined by an equivalence relation over $[b]$, and thus, $|M| \leq b^{b}$. Therefore, Eq. (2) is satisfied, making $\mathcal{P}$ reasonable.

In the classic local property framework (see [MRRSW20]), the number of types associated with a b-local property is equal to the number of ways to distribute $n$ unlabeled balls between $q^{b}$ labeled bins, a term which grows exponentially in $q$. In the present LCL framework, $|M|$ can be seen as analogous to the base $n$ logarithm of the number of types. The fact that $|M|$ can remain constant as $q$ grows is crucial to the suitability of LCL properties for studying the large alphabet regime.

In Section 5 we use the characterization mentioned in Remark 3.2 to compute the threshold rate for (average-weight) list-decodability and to give an upper bound on the threshold for listrecoverability.

Theorem 3.4 (RLC threshold for list-decodability). Fix $\rho \in[0,1]$ and $L \in$ $\mathbb{N}$. Consider the properties $\mathcal{P}:=\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, L)$-list-decodable $\}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}:=$ $\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, L)$-average-weight list-decodable $\}$. Then,

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}} \geq R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \geq \max \left\{1-\rho \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right), 0\right\}
$$

Furthermore, if $n$ is divisible by $\binom{L+1}{(1-\rho)(L+1)}$ then the above bound is tight, namely,

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}}=R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}}=\max \left\{1-\rho \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right), 0\right\}
$$

Remark 3.5. The hard part of this theorem is proving the lower bound on $R_{\mathcal{P}}$. This is a positive result about RLCs, which also follows from [AGL23]. The reasoning in [AGL23] relies on that paper's main result about random RS codes, and, in particular, on the GM-MDS theorem. In contrast, our proof is more direct and elementary.

Our upper bound on $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ can also be inferred from the generalized Singleton bound [GST22] (see Section 1.4.3). Here we prove it directly (assuming the proper divisibility condition) within the LCL framework.

1. If $R \leq 1-\rho \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)-\varepsilon$ then $\mathcal{C}$ is $(\rho, L)$-list-decodable with probability at least $1-2^{n \cdot(L+1)}$. $q^{-\varepsilon n+(L+1)^{2}}$.
2. In particular, if $R \leq 1-\rho \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)-\varepsilon$ and $q>2^{\frac{2(L+1)}{\varepsilon}}$ then $\mathcal{C}$ is $(\rho, L)$-average-weight list-decodable with probability at least $1-q^{-\frac{\varepsilon n}{2}+(L+1)^{2}}$.

Consider the properties $\mathcal{P}:=\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable $\}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}:=$ $\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, \ell, L)$-average-weight list-recoverable $\}$. $$
R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \leq R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\right)\left(1-\frac{L+1}{L+1-\ell} \cdot \rho\right)

# 3.2 The Equivalence Theorem and Results About Random Reed-Solomon Codes 

In Sections 6 and 7 we prove the equivalence between RLCs and random RS codes.
Theorem 3.10 (Threshold theorem for RS codes). Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a b-LCL property of codes in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, with associated local profile family $\mathcal{F} \subseteq \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)^{n}$. Let $0<R<1$ and let $\mathcal{C}=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k\right)$, where $k=R n$ and $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are sampled independently and uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}$. Assume that $q>k b$. Fix $\varepsilon n \geq 2 b(b+1)$. The following now holds:

1. If $R \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}-\varepsilon$, then

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C} \text { satisfies } \mathcal{P}] \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{\varepsilon n}{2 b}} \cdot|\mathcal{F}|
$$

2. If $R \geq R_{\mathcal{P}}+\varepsilon$, then

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C} \text { satisfies } \mathcal{P}] \geq 1-\binom{b}{2} \cdot\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{\varepsilon n}{2 b}}
$$

For a fixed LCL property $\mathcal{P}$, Theorem 3.10 reveals a threshold phenomenon for random RS codes. Specifically, $\mathcal{P}$ is highly likely to be satisfied when $R>R_{\mathcal{P}}$ and almost certainly not satisfied when $R<R_{\mathcal{P}}$. The sharpness of this transition increases rapidly with $q$. Crucially, the threshold matches that of RLCs, implying that an RLC and a random RS code with similar rates are likely to satisfy the same local properties. Indeed, any positive result about local properties of RLCs can immediately be transferred to random RS codes, and vice versa. We illustrate this paradigm by the following corollary.

$$
q \geq 2^{\frac{r}{\varepsilon}} \cdot n
$$

Let $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ be an $R L C$ of rate $R$ and let $\mathcal{D} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ be a random $R S$ code of rate $R^{\prime}:=R-\varepsilon-\frac{c^{\prime}}{n}$, where $\varepsilon \geq \frac{c^{\prime \prime}}{n}$. Suppose that

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{D} \text { is }(\rho, \ell, L) \text {-list-recoverable }] \geq 1-2^{-n}
$$

# 4 LCL Properties of Random Linear Codes 

The following is a basic property of an RLC.
Lemma 4.1 (Probability that an RLC contains a set). Let $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ be an $R L C$ of rate $R$ and let $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}$. Then

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[A \subseteq \mathcal{C}]=q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{rank} A}
$$

Proof. Write $\mathcal{C}=\operatorname{ker} P$ where $P \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{(1-R) n \times n}$ is uniformly random. Now,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[A \subseteq \mathcal{C}]=\operatorname{Pr}[\forall i \in[(1-R) n] \quad P_{i *} \cdot A=0]=\prod_{i=1}^{(1-R) n} \operatorname{Pr}\left[P_{i *} \cdot A=0\right]=q^{-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{rank} A}
$$

We are interested in the probability that an RLC $\mathcal{C}$ of rate $R$ satisfies a given $b$-LCL property $\mathcal{P}$. In particular, we would like to estimate $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ contains $\mathcal{V}]$ for a given linear profile $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)^{n}$. As a first-order estimate, it makes sense to first compute the expectation

$$
E\left|\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }} \mid A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right\}\right|=\sum_{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}} \operatorname{Pr}[A \subseteq \mathcal{C}]=\sum_{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}} q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{rank} A}
$$

where the last transition is due to Lemma 4.1. As we shall see, to understand the likelihood of $\mathcal{C}$ containing $\mathcal{V}$ we will need a more nuanced expectation argument, in which we classify the matrices in $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}$ according to their row span. For each $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ we define

$$
\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}=\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}} \mid \text { row-span }(A)=U\right\}
$$

If there exists $A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}$ such that $A \subseteq \mathcal{C}$, we say that $\mathcal{C}$ contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)$. Let

$$
\mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)=\left\{U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \mid \forall 1 \leq i<j \leq b \exists x \in U \text { such that } x_{i} \neq x_{j}\right\}
$$

and note that a matrix $A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}$ belongs to $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}$ if and only if row-span $(A) \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$. Hence,

$$
\max _{U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)} \operatorname{Pr}\left[\exists A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}, A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right] \leq \operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { contains } \mathcal{V}\right] \leq \sum_{U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)} \operatorname{Pr}\left[\exists A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}, A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right]
$$

Observe that the left-hand and right-hand sides differ by a factor of at most $\left|\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right| \leq q^{b^{2}}$. For constant $b$, this is merely polynomial in $q$ and will thus end up being negligible. We therefore turn to estimating the probability that $\mathcal{C}$ contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)$ for a given fixed $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$. Analogously to Eq. (5), we have
$\mathbb{E}\left\|\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U} \mid A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right\}\right\|=\sum_{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}} q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{rank} A}=\sum_{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}} q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U}=\left|\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}\right| \cdot q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U}$.
To bound the right-hand side we need to bound the term $\left|\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}\right|$. To this end, we define

$$
\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}=\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}} \mid \text { row-span }(A) \subseteq U\right\}
$$

and note that $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U} \subseteq \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}$. Notice that even when $U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Diat }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$, the set $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}$ will also include some matrices with non-distinct columns, in contrast to $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}$. In particular, observe that the all-zero matrix is always an element of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}$.

The cardinality of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}$ is easier to compute than that of $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}$ since the former is a linear subspace of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}$. Indeed, a matrix $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}$ belongs to $\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}$ if and only if $A_{i *} \in \mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U$ for all $i \in[n]$. Hence,

$$
\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)
$$

Defining the potential function ${ }^{10}$

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R):=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U
$$

we conclude from Eq. (6) that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U} \mid A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right\}\right|\right] & =\left|\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}\right| \cdot q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U} \leq\left|\mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*}\right| \cdot q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U} \\
& =q^{\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}^{*} \cdot q^{-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U}} \\
& =q^{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)}
\end{aligned}
$$

When $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \geq \Omega(n)$ we shall say that the potential is large, whereas a potential satisfying $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq-\Omega(n)$ will be called small. In our informal discussion we will ignore the middle case in which a potential is neither large nor small. To justify this dichotomy, observe that a potential is "almost always" either large or small. Namely, if $-\omega(n) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq \omega(n)$ then for any fixed $\varepsilon$ we have $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R+\varepsilon)=\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)+\varepsilon n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \geq \Omega(n)$ and $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R-\varepsilon)=$ $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\varepsilon n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \leq-\Omega(n)$.

Eq. (9) yields an immediate upper bound on the probability that $\mathcal{C}$ contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)$. Namely, Markov's bound yields
$\operatorname{Pr}\left[\exists A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U}, A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right]=\operatorname{Pr}\left[\left|\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U} \mid A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right\}\right| \geq 1\right] \leq \mathbb{E}\left\|\left\{A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U} \mid A \subseteq \mathcal{C}\right\}\right\| \leq q^{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)}$.
Hence, $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)$ being large is a necessary condition for $\mathcal{C}$ to be likely to contain $(\mathcal{V}, U)$. One immediately wonders whether this is also a sufficient condition. The answer turns out to be no. In the following example, $\mathcal{C}$ is very unlikely to contain $(\mathcal{V}, U)$ despite $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)$ being large.

Proposition 4.3 (RLC Thresholds for linear profiles). Let $n \in \mathbb{N}$, and let $q$ be a prime power (which may depend on $n$ ). Let $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ be an $R L C$ of rate $R \in[0,1]$.

Fix $b \in \mathbb{N}$ and $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash\{\{0\}\}$ and let $\mathcal{V} \in\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)^{n}$. Let

$$
M=\min \left\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \mid W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \text { and } W \subsetneq U\right\}
$$

The following then holds.

1. If $M<0$ then $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)] \leq q^{M}$.
2. If $M>0$ then $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)] \geq 1-q^{-M+b^{2}}$.

Before proving Proposition 4.3, we discuss the proposition and its implications. We first note that $\Phi(\mathcal{V},\{0\}, R)=0$ for every $\mathcal{V}$ and $R$. Hence, the condition $M>0$ in the proposition implies in particular that $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)=\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V},\{0\}, R)>0$. As we have already seen in Eq. (9), large potential is indeed a necessary condition for $\mathcal{C}$ to be likely to contain $(\mathcal{V}, U)$.

Let us now revisit Example 4.2 in light of Proposition 4.3. In that example, consider the vector space $W=\left\{x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{2} \mid x_{1}=x_{2}\right\}$. It is not difficult to see that $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)=R n$, which is larger than $\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{2}, R\right)=\left(2 R-\frac{1}{2}\right) n$ whenever $R<\frac{1}{2}$. Proposition 4.3 thus implies that an RLC of rate $<\frac{1}{2}$ is unlikely to contain $\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{2}\right)$. In Example 4.2 we reached a similar conclusion by projecting the rows of a matrix $A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{2}}$ onto their difference. The kernel of this projection $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{2} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{1}$ is exactly $W$. The proof of the first part of Proposition 4.3 generalizes this method. The second part of the proposition says that this method is essentially tight.

We refer to Proposition 4.3 as a threshold result since, given $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash\{\{0\}\}$ and $\mathcal{V} \in$ $\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)^{n}$, the proposition gives a threshold rate $R_{\mathcal{V}, U}$ such that, essentially, an RLC of rate below the threshold is very unlikely to contain $(\mathcal{V}, U)$, while an RLC of rate above the threshold almost surely contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)$. The threshold rate is given by

$$
R_{\mathcal{V}, U}:=\max _{\substack{W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \\ W \subseteq U}}\left\{1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\operatorname{dim}(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W)\right)}{n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim} W)}\right\}
$$

Indeed, one can verify that the term $M$ in Proposition 4.3 is positive if and only if $R>R_{\mathcal{V}, U}$. In other words,

$$
R_{\mathcal{V}, U}=\min \{R \in[0,1] \mid \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \geq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \text { for every linear subspace } W \subseteq U\}
$$

Recall that a code $\mathcal{C}$ is said to contain $\mathcal{V}$ if and only if it contains $(\mathcal{V}, U)$ for some $U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$. We thus define

$$
R_{\mathcal{V}}:=\min _{U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)}\left\{R_{\mathcal{V}, U}\right\}=\min _{U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)} \max _{\substack{W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \\ W \subseteq U}}\left\{1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)\right)}{n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim} W)}\right\}
$$

Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a $b$-LCL property whose associated profile family is $\mathcal{F}$. Recall that $\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\mathcal{P}$, if $\mathcal{C}$ contains some $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}$. We thus define

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}}:=\min _{\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}}\left\{R_{\mathcal{V}}\right\}=\min _{\substack{\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F} \\ U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)}}\left\{R_{\mathcal{V}, U}\right\}
$$

1. If $R \geq R_{\mathcal{P}}+\varepsilon$ then $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\left.\mathcal{P}] \geq 1-q^{-\varepsilon n+b^{2}}$.
2. If $R \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}-\varepsilon$ then $\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\left.\mathcal{P}] \leq|\mathcal{F}| \cdot q^{-\varepsilon n+b^{2}}$.

$$
M=\min \left\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \mid W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \text { and } W \subsetneq U\right\}
$$

M:=\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)=g-(1-R) n \cdot d \geq g-\left(1-R_{\mathcal{V}, U}-\varepsilon\right) n \cdot d \geq \varepsilon n d \geq \varepsilon n
$$

Therefore, by Proposition 4.3,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C} \text { satisfies } \mathcal{P}] \geq \operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C} \text { contains }(\mathcal{V}, U)] \geq 1-q^{-M+b^{2}} \geq 1-q^{-\varepsilon n+b^{2}}

$$
M_{\mathcal{V}, U} \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)=g-n d(1-R) \leq-\varepsilon n d
$$

so

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C} \text { contains }(\mathcal{V}, U)] \leq q^{-\varepsilon n d} \leq q^{-\varepsilon n}

by Proposition 4.3. Now,
$\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}$ satisfies $\left.\mathcal{P}] \leq \sum_{\mathcal{V} \in \mathbb{F}} \sum_{U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)} \operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C}\right.$ contains $\left.(\mathcal{V}, U)] \leq|\mathcal{F}| \cdot\left|\mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right| \cdot q^{-\varepsilon n}=|\mathcal{F}| \cdot q^{-\varepsilon n+b^{2}}$.
