2. For all $R \in\left(R_{\mathcal{V}}, 1\right]$ we have $\operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, *, R)\} \subseteq \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$.
3. $\operatorname{argmax}\left\{\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, *, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)\right\}$ contains an element of $\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ and an element of $\mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$.

The following is an immediate corollary obtained by taking the contrapositives of the two statements in Lemma 4.5.

Corollary 4.6. Let $n, b \in \mathbb{N}$, $q$ a prime power and $\mathcal{V} \in\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)^{n}$. Let $R \in[0,1]$. The following holds.

1. If $\operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, *, R)\}$ contains an element of $\mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ then $R \geq R_{\mathcal{V}}$.
2. If $\operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, *, R)\}$ contains an element of $\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ then $R \leq R_{\mathcal{V}}$.

Our proof of Lemma 4.5 relies on the following lemma, which we prove immediately after Lemma 4.5.

Lemma 4.7. Let $n, b \in \mathbb{N}, q$ a prime power, $\mathcal{V} \in\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)^{n}$. Fix $R \in[0,1]$ and let $U, W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$. Then,

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)+\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U \cap W, R)+\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U+W, R)
$$

Proof of Lemma 4.5. The third statement follows from the first two since $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)$ is continuous in $R$.

We will prove the contrapositives of the first two statements. For the first statement, suppose there exists some $U \in \operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(V, *, R)\} \cap \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$. We need to show that $R \geq R_{\mathcal{V}}$. Indeed, by Eq. (13),

$$
R_{\mathcal{V}} \leq R_{\mathcal{V}, U}=\max _{\substack{W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \\ W \subseteq U}}\left\{1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)\right)}{n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim} W)}\right\}
$$

Fix $W \subsetneq U$. To prove that $R \geq R_{\mathcal{V}}$ it suffices to show that

$$
R \geq 1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)\right)}{n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim} W)}
$$

The above is equivalent to $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \geq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)$, which follows from our assumption that $U \in \operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(V, *, R)\} \cap \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$

We turn to the second statement. We now assume that there is some $W \in \operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(V, *, R)\} \cap$ $\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)$ and need to prove that $R \leq R_{\mathcal{V}}$. Fix $U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$. By Eq. (13), it suffices to prove that $R \leq R_{\mathcal{V}, U}$. By Eq. (11), the latter would follow if we show that

$$
R \leq 1-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W^{\prime}\right)\right)}{n \cdot\left(\operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim} W^{\prime}\right)}
$$

for some $W^{\prime} \subsetneq U$. We take $W^{\prime}=W \cap U$. Note that $W^{\prime}$ is indeed strictly contained in $U$ since $W \notin \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ and thus so does any subspace of $W$, including $W^{\prime}$. By assumption, $U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$, so $W^{\prime} \neq U$ and thus the containment is indeed strict. Now, Eq. (18) is equivalent to the statement

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U \cap W, R)
$$

By Lemma 4.7,

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U \cap W, R)+\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U+W, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U \cap W, R)
$$

where the second inequality is due to the maximality of $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)$.
Proof of Lemma 4.7. Fix $Z \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{P}_{q}^{b}\right)$. Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{dim}(U \cap W \cap Z)+\operatorname{dim}((U+W) \cap Z) & \geq \operatorname{dim}(U \cap W \cap Z)+\operatorname{dim}((U \cap Z)+(W \cap Z)) \\
& =\operatorname{dim}(U \cap Z)+\operatorname{dim}(W \cap Z)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U \cap W, R)+\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U+W, R) \\
= & \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap W \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)+\operatorname{dim}\left((U+W) \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim}(U \cap W)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim}(U+W)\right) \\
\geq & \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)+\operatorname{dim}\left(W \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim}(U \cap W)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim}(U+W)\right) \\
= & \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)+\operatorname{dim}\left(W \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim}(U)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim}(W)\right) \\
= & \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)+\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)
\end{aligned}
$$

# 5 List-Decodability and List-Recoverability of RLCs 

In this section we use the characterization of the threshold rate, given in Eq. (14), to compute the threshold for list-decodability and average-weight list-decodability of RLCs. We then prove an upper bound on the threshold for list-recoverability and average-weight list-recoverability of RLCs.

### 5.1 Threshold for List-Decodability

In this section we prove the following result.
Theorem 3.4 (RLC threshold for list-decodability). Fix $\rho \in[0,1]$ and $L \in$ $\mathbb{N}$. Consider the properties $\mathcal{P}:=\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, L)$-list-decodable $\}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}:=$ $\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, L)$-average-weight list-decodable $\}$. Then,

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}} \geq R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \geq \max \left\{1-\rho \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right), 0\right\}
$$

Furthermore, if $n$ is divisible by $\binom{L+1}{(1-\rho)(L+1)}$ then the above bound is tight, namely,

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}}=R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}}=\max \left\{1-\rho \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right), 0\right\}
$$

Proof.

# Notation for This Proof: 

We first set up some notation. Given a set $Z \subseteq[L+1]$, let

$$
D_{Z}:=\left\{x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1} \mid \operatorname{supp}(x) \subseteq Z\right\}
$$

and let

$$
E_{Z}:=\left\{x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1} \mid \forall i, j \in Z, i=j\right\}
$$

Let

$$
E:=E_{[L+1]}=\left\{x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1} \mid \forall i, j \quad x_{i}=x_{j}\right\}
$$

Let $\mathcal{F}, \mathcal{F}^{\prime} \subseteq \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)^{n}$ denote the local profiles families associated with $\mathcal{P}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}$, respectively. Observe that every profile in $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}$ is of the form $\mathcal{V}_{i}=E_{Z_{i}}(i \in[n])$, where:

- $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}$ are non-empty subsets of $[L+1]$.
- For each $j \in[L+1]$, it holds that $\left|\left\{i \in[n] \mid j \in Z_{i}\right\}\right| \geq(1-\rho) n$.

Profiles in $\mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ are of similar form, except that the second condition is relaxed to $\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|Z_{i}\right| \geq$ $(L+1) \cdot(1-\rho) \cdot n$.

Clearly, $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ and $R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}}$ are both monotone-decreasing in $\rho$. Hence, it suffices to prove the theorem under the assumption that $\rho \leq 1-\frac{1}{L+1}$, and so, $1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right) \geq 0$. Also, note that $R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}$. Thus, to prove the theorem it is enough to separately prove the inequalities $R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \geq 1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)$ and $R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq 1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)$.

Proof of $R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \geq 1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)$ :
Let $R=1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)$. We claim that for every $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}^{\prime}$ and $U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)$ there exists $W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)$ such that

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)
$$

This would imply that $\operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, *, R)\} \cap\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)\right)$ is nonempty, whence $R_{\mathcal{V}} \geq$ $R$ by virtue of Corollary 4.6, and therefore $R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \geq R$ by Eq. (14).

To prove Eq. (19) we consider two cases. First, if $U+E=\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$, we take $W=E$. Observe that $E \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)$ and

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap E\right)-(1-R) \operatorname{dim} E \cdot n=\sum_{i=1}^{n} 1-(1-R) \cdot n=R \cdot n
$$

On the other hand,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap E_{Z_{i}}\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim} U+\operatorname{dim} E_{Z_{i}}-\operatorname{dim}\left(U+E_{Z_{i}}\right)\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim} U+\operatorname{dim} E_{Z_{i}}-(L+1)\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim} U+\left(L+2-\left|Z_{i}\right|\right)-(L+1)\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim} U+1-\left|Z_{i}\right|\right)-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n \\
& \leq\left(\operatorname{dim} U-(1-\rho) \cdot(L+1)+1\right) \cdot n-(1-R) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n \\
& =(\operatorname{dim} U-L) \cdot R n \leq R n=\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields Eq. (19).
For the second case, suppose that $K:=U+E \subsetneq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$. For a set $J \subseteq[L+1]$, denote $f(J):=\operatorname{dim}\left(K \cap D_{J}\right)$. We claim that there exists a set $T \subseteq[L+1]$ with the following properties:

1. $|T| \geq 2$
2. $f(T)=1$
3. Every nonempty $T^{\prime} \subsetneq T$ has $f\left(T^{\prime}\right)=0$.

We turn to construct such a set. Let $I=\{i \in[L+1] \mid e_{i} \notin K\}$. Observe that $I \neq \emptyset$ by our assumption that $K \neq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$. Note that $f(\{i\})=0$ for all $i \in I$.

On the other hand, we claim that $\mathbf{1}_{I} \in K \cap D_{I}$, so $f(I) \geq 1$. Indeed, $\mathbf{1} \in E$, so it is also in $K=U+E$. By definition of $I$ we have $e_{i} \in K$ for all $i \in[L+1] \backslash I$. Thus, $\mathbf{1}_{I}=\mathbf{1}-\sum_{j \in[L+1] \backslash I} e_{j} \in$ $K \cap D_{I}$.

Hence, one can take $T \subseteq I$ to be an inclusion-minimal nonempty set with $f(T) \geq 1$. We show that $T$ satisfies Conditions 1 to 3 above. Condition 3 follows immediately from the minimality of $T$. Condition 1 holds since $f(\{i\})=0$ for all $i \in I$, implying that $|T|>1$. Finally, let some $z \in T$ and observe that $f(T) \leq f(T \backslash\{z\})+1=1$, where the equality is due to Condition 3 . Since $f(T) \geq 1$ by the definition of $T$, Condition 2 follows.

Take $W=\left(K+D_{T}\right) \cap E_{T}$. Note that $W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)$. We turn to prove that $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)$.

For $t \in T$, define the linear map $\varphi_{t}(x): K \rightarrow W$ by

$$
\varphi_{t}(x)= \begin{cases}x_{j}, & j \notin T \\ x_{t}, & j \in T\end{cases}
$$

We claim that $\varphi_{t}$ is a bijection. First we establish that the image is indeed contained in $W$. It is evident that $\varphi_{t}(x) \in E_{T}$ and $\varphi_{t}(x)-x \in D_{T}$. Therefore, $\varphi_{t}(x)=x+\left(\varphi_{t}(x)-x\right) \in K+D_{T}$ and thus $\varphi_{t}(x) \in\left(K+D_{T}\right) \cap E_{T}=W$.

To prove injectivity of $\varphi_{t}$, assume there is a non-zero $x \in K$ such that $\varphi_{t}(x)=0$. Let $T^{\prime}=T \backslash\{t\}$. The definition of $\varphi$ implies that $x_{i}=0$ for all $i \in([L+1] \backslash T) \cup\{t\}$, so $x \in D_{T^{\prime}}$. By Condition 3, $K \cap D_{T^{\prime}}=\{0\}$, so $x=0$.

Finally, to prove surjectivity of $\varphi_{t}$, let $w \in W$. Since $W=\left(K+D_{T}\right) \cap E_{T}$, there are $x \in K$ and $y \in D_{T}$ such that $x+y=w$. By Conditions 2 and 3, there is a vector $z \in K$ whose support is exactly $T$. Evidently, $w=\varphi_{t}(x+\alpha z)$ for some $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$.

We now claim that $\operatorname{dim}\left(K \cap E_{Z}\right) \leq \operatorname{dim}\left(W \cap E_{Z}\right)$ for every $Z \subseteq[L+1]$. If $Z \cap T=\emptyset$ choose an arbitrary $t \in T$ and if $Z \cap T \neq \emptyset$ choose some $t \in Z \cap T$. The claim follows since, in both cases, $\varphi_{t}$ injectively maps $K \cap E_{Z}$ to $W \cap E_{Z}$.

Note that $\operatorname{dim} W=\operatorname{dim} K$ since there is a bijection between $W$ and $K$. This and the above inequality imply

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} W \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(E_{Z_{i}} \cap W\right)-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} K \\
& \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(E_{Z_{i}} \cap K\right)-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} K=\Phi(\mathcal{V}, K, R)
\end{aligned}
$$

Lastly, denote $d:=\operatorname{dim} K-\operatorname{dim} U$, and observe that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, K, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap K\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)\right)-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot d \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} d-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot d=\operatorname{Rnd} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

and thus $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \geq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)$.
Proof of $R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq 1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)$ :
Let $R=1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)$. We will construct a linear profile $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}$ such that

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq \Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}, R\right)
$$

for every subspace $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$. This would imply that $\operatorname{argmax}\{\Phi(\mathcal{V}, *, R)\} \cap \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)$ is nonempty, whence $R_{\mathcal{V}} \leq R$ by virtue of Corollary 4.6. Eq. (14) then yields

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq R_{\mathcal{V}} \leq R=1-\rho\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)
$$

We now describe the aforementioned linear profile $\mathcal{V}$. Let $s:=(1-\rho)(L+1)$. Note that $0 \leq \rho \leq \frac{L}{L+1}$. Write $t=\binom{L+1}{s}$. Recall that $n$ is divisible by $t$. Let the sequence $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}$ consist of $\frac{n}{t}$ instances of each subset of $[L+1]$ of size $s$. Let $\mathcal{V}_{i}=E_{Z_{i}}$ for all $i \in[n]$. Observe that $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}$. We turn to proving Eq. (20).

First, observe that

$$
\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{V}_{i}=\operatorname{dim} E_{Z_{i}}=L+2-\left|Z_{i}\right|=(L+1) \cdot \rho+1
$$

so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}, R\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim} \mathcal{V}_{i}-n(L+1)(1-R) & =n \cdot((L+1) \cdot \rho+1-(L+1)(1-R)) \\
& =n \cdot\left(\frac{(L+1)(1-\rho)-1}{L}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, let $U \subsetneq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$. We need to show that Eq. (20) holds with regard to $U$. Denote $d:=\operatorname{dim} U$. We provide an alternative formulation of $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)$ in terms of linear maps. Let $\phi: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1-d}$ be a full rank linear map such that $\operatorname{ker} \phi=U$. We can write

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) & =\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-(1-R) n d \\
& =\sum_{i}\left(\operatorname{dim} \mathcal{V}_{i}-\operatorname{dim}\left(\phi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right)\right)\right)-(1-R) n d \\
& =\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim} \mathcal{V}_{i}-\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim}\left(\phi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right)\right)-(1-R) n d \\
& =((L+1) \cdot \rho+1) \cdot n-\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim}\left(\phi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right)\right)-\frac{L-(1-\rho)(L+1)+1}{L} \cdot n d
\end{aligned}
$$

We turn to bound the term $\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim}\left(\phi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right)\right)$. Denote $L^{\prime}:=L+1-d$. Let $M \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L^{\prime} \times(L+1)}$ be a matrix representing the linear map $\phi$ in the standard basis. Because $\phi$ is full rank, $M$ has rank exactly $L^{\prime}$. Therefore, there exists a set of linearly independent columns from $M$ of size exactly $L^{\prime}$. Denote the coordinates of such a set of columns by $I \subseteq[L+1]$ (so $|I|=L^{\prime}$ ). Let $\pi: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L^{\prime}}$ denote the projection map into the coordinate set $I$. Let $M^{\prime} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L^{\prime} \times L^{\prime}}$ denote the restriction of the matrix $M$ to the columns indicated by $I$, and let $\phi^{\prime}: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L^{\prime}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L^{\prime}}$ be the bijective linear map represented by $M^{\prime}$. Observe that for any linear space $V \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$ we have

$$
\operatorname{dim} \phi(V) \geq \operatorname{dim} \phi^{\prime}(\pi(V))=\operatorname{dim} \pi(V)
$$

In particular, if $V=E_{Z}$ for some $Z \subseteq[L+1]$ then

$$
\operatorname{dim} \phi(V) \geq \operatorname{dim} \pi(V)=L^{\prime}+1-\max \{|I \cap Z|, 1\}
$$

Thus,

$$
\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim} \phi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right)=\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim} \phi\left(E_{Z_{i}}\right) \geq n \cdot\left(L^{\prime}+1-\mathbb{E}_{Z}[\max \{|I \cap Z|, 1\}]\right)
$$

where the expectation is over a uniformly random set $Z \subseteq[L+1]$ of size $s$. Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{Z}[\max \{|I \cap Z|, 1\}]=\mathbb{E}[|I \cap Z|]+\operatorname{Pr}[|I \cap Z|=0] & =(1-\rho) L^{\prime}+\frac{\binom{L+1-s}{L^{\prime}}}{\binom{L+1}{L^{\prime}}} \\
& \leq(1-\rho) L^{\prime}+\left(\frac{d}{L+1}\right)^{s} \\
& =(1-\rho) L^{\prime}+\left(\frac{d}{L+1}\right)^{(1-\rho)(L+1)}
\end{aligned}
$$

We claim that $\left(\frac{d}{(L+1)}\right)^{(1-\rho)(L+1)} \leq 1-\frac{L^{\prime} \cdot \rho}{L+1}$ for all $0 \leq \rho \leq \frac{L}{L+1}$. Since the left-hand side is convex in $\rho$, it suffices to verify the claim for $\rho=0$ and $\rho=\frac{L}{L+1}$, both of which are straightforward to check. We conclude that

$$
\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim} \phi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right) \geq n \cdot\left(L^{\prime}+1-(1-\rho) L^{\prime}-\left(1-\frac{L^{\prime} \cdot \rho}{L}\right)\right)=n \cdot \rho \cdot L^{\prime} \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{L}\right)
$$

By the above and Eq. (21),

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq n \cdot\left(\frac{(L+1)(1-\rho)-1}{L}\right)=\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}, R\right)
$$

Eq. (20) follows.

# 5.2 A Negative Bound for List-Recoverability 

Our goal in this section is to prove the following theorem.
Theorem 3.8 (Upper bound on RLC threshold for list-recoverability). Fix $\rho \in[0,1]$ and $\ell, L \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\ell \geq 2$ and $L+1=\ell^{m}$ for some $m \in \mathbb{N}$. Consider the properties $\mathcal{P}:=\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable $\}$ and $\mathcal{P}^{\prime}:=$ $\left\{\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n} \mid \mathcal{C}\right.$ is not $(\rho, \ell, L)$-average-weight list-recoverable $\}$. Suppose that $n \cdot\left(1-\frac{L+1}{L+1-\ell} \cdot \rho\right)$ is divisible by $m$ and $(L+1) \rho n$ is divisible by $\binom{L+1}{\ell}$. Then,

$$
R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \leq R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\right)\left(1-\frac{L+1}{L+1-\ell} \cdot \rho\right)
$$

Proof. Let $\alpha:=1-\frac{L+1}{L+1-\ell} \cdot \rho$ and $R=\left(1-\frac{1}{m}\right) \cdot \alpha$. We construct a profile $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)^{n}$ that belongs to the local profile family associated with $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverability. We then prove that $R_{\mathcal{V}} \leq R$. Eq. (14) then yields $R_{\mathcal{P}} \leq R$. This suffices to prove the theorem, since, clearly, $R_{\mathcal{P}^{\prime}} \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}$.

We turn to describe the profile $\mathcal{V}$. Given $x \in[L+1]$ and $i \in[m]$, let $(x)_{i}$ denote the $i$-th symbol in the $\ell$-ary representation of $x$. For $i \in[m]$, let

$$
E_{i}=\left\{u \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1} \mid \forall x, y \in[L+1] \quad(x)_{i}=(y)_{i} \Longrightarrow u_{x}=u_{y}\right\}
$$

In the profile $\mathcal{V}$, each of the subspaces $E_{j}(j \in[L+1])$ appears $\frac{n \cdot \alpha}{m}$ times. The other $(1-\alpha) \cdot n$ entries of $\mathcal{V}$ are $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}$. Let $G=\left\{i \in[n] \mid \mathcal{V}_{i}=\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right\}$.

Observe that a code containing $\mathcal{V}$ is not $(\rho, \ell, L)$-list-recoverable. Indeed, let $A \in \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}$. We claim that the columns of $A$ are $(\rho, \ell)$-recovery-clustered. This is straightforward to verify given the input lists $Z_{1}, \ldots, Z_{n}$ that we now define. For $i \in[n] \backslash G$ take $Z_{i}$ to be the set of all letters in $A_{i *}$ and observe that this is a set of size at most $\ell$. Next, fix sets $P_{i}$ for all $i \in G$ such that when $i$ is uniformly sampled from $G$, the set $P_{i}$ is uniform over $\binom{[L+1]}{\ell}$. For $i \in G$, let $Z_{i}=\left\{A_{i, j} \mid j \in P_{i}\right\}$.

Let $U$ denote the linear space $\sum_{i=1}^{m} E_{i}$. Clearly, $U \in \mathcal{L}^{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{L+1}\right)$, since every $x \neq y \in[L+1]$ have some $i \in[m]$ for which $(x)_{i} \neq(y)_{i}$. We claim that $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \geq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)$ for every linear subspace $W \subseteq U$. By Eqs. (12) and (13), this implies that $R_{\mathcal{V}} \leq R_{\mathcal{V}, U} \leq R$, and the lemma follows.

To proceed, we need the observation that

$$
E_{j} \cap\left(\sum_{j^{\prime} \in[m] \backslash\{j\}} E_{j^{\prime}}\right)=\operatorname{span}\{\mathbf{1}\}
$$

for all $j \in[m]$. Indeed, let $u \in E_{j}$ and suppose that $u \notin \operatorname{span} \mathbf{1}$. Then, there exist $x, y \in[L+1]$ such that $u_{x} \neq u_{y}$. Let $z \in[L+1]$ such that $(z)_{j}=(y)_{j}$, and $(z)_{r}=(x)_{r}$ for all $r \in[m] \backslash\{j\}$. Note that $u_{z}=u_{y}$ since $z \sim_{j} y$. Hence, $u_{z} \neq u_{x}$. But, $z \sim_{r} x$ for all $r \neq j$, so $v_{x}=v_{y}$ for all $v \in \sum_{j^{\prime} \in[m] \backslash\{j\}} E_{\sim_{j^{\prime}}}$. Therefore, $u \notin \sum_{j^{\prime} \in[m] \backslash\{j\}} E_{\sim_{j^{\prime}}}$.

By Eq. (22), $\operatorname{dim} U=(\ell-1) m+1$. Hence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) & =\sum_{i \in[n] \backslash G} \operatorname{dim}\left(V_{i} \cap U\right)+\sum_{i \in G} \operatorname{dim}\left(V_{i} \cap U\right)-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \\
& =\alpha \cdot n \cdot \ell+(1-\alpha) \cdot n \cdot((\ell-1) m+1)-(1-R) \cdot n \cdot((\ell-1) m+1) \\
& =n \cdot(((\ell-1) m+1) R-(\ell-1)(m-1) \alpha)=n \cdot R
\end{aligned}
$$

Let $W \subseteq U$ be a linear subspace that maximizes $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)$. We may assume that $\mathbf{1} \in W$ since otherwise
$\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W+\operatorname{span}\{\mathbf{1}\}, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\operatorname{span}\{\mathbf{1}\} \cap \mathcal{V}_{i}\right)-(1-R) n=n-(1-R) n=R \geq 0$.
Let $W^{\prime} \subseteq W$ be a subspace such that $W=\operatorname{span}\{\mathbf{1}\}+W^{\prime}$. Similarly, for $i \in[m]$, let $E_{i}^{\prime} \subseteq E_{i}$ be a subspace for which $E_{i}=\operatorname{span}\{\mathbf{1}\}+E_{i}^{\prime}$. Now,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{i \in[m]} \operatorname{dim}\left(E_{i} \cap W\right) & \leq \sum_{i \in[m]}\left(\operatorname{dim} E_{i}+\operatorname{dim} W-\operatorname{dim}\left(E_{i}+W\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{i \in[m]}\left(2+\operatorname{dim} E_{i}^{\prime}+\operatorname{dim} W^{\prime}-\operatorname{dim}\left(E_{i}+W\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{i \in[m]}\left(2+\operatorname{dim} E_{i}^{\prime}+\operatorname{dim} W^{\prime}-\operatorname{dim}\left(\operatorname{span}\left\{\overrightarrow{1}\right\}+E_{i}^{\prime}+W^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{i \in[m]}\left(1+\operatorname{dim} E_{i}^{\prime}+\operatorname{dim} W^{\prime}-\operatorname{dim}\left(E_{i}^{\prime}+W^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{i \in[m]}\left(1+\operatorname{dim}\left(E_{i}^{\prime} \cap W^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& \leq m+\operatorname{dim} W^{\prime}=m+\operatorname{dim} W-1
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality is due to Eq. (22). Therefore, taking $D:=\operatorname{dim} W$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) & =\sum_{i \in[n] \backslash G} \operatorname{dim}\left(V_{i} \cap W\right)+\sum_{i \in G} \operatorname{dim}\left(V_{i} \cap W\right)-(1-R) \cdot D \\
& \leq \alpha \cdot n \cdot \frac{m+D-1}{m}+(1-\alpha) \cdot n \cdot D-(1-R) \cdot D \\
& =n \cdot\left(D R-\frac{(D-1)(m-1)}{m} \cdot \alpha\right)=n \cdot R \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)
\end{aligned}
$$

# 6 Random RS Codes and RLCs are locally equivalent 

In this section we prove our main theorem about random RS codes, restated below.
Theorem 3.10 (Threshold theorem for RS codes). Let $\mathcal{P}$ be a b-LCL property of codes in $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$, with associated local profile family $\mathcal{F} \subseteq \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)^{n}$. Let $0<R<1$ and let $\mathcal{C}=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k\right)$, where $k=R n$ and $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are sampled independently and uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}$. Assume that $q>k b$. Fix $\varepsilon n \geq 2 b(b+1)$. The following now holds:

1. If $R \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}-\varepsilon$, then

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { satisfies } \mathcal{P}\right] \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{2 b}{2 b}} \cdot|\mathcal{F}|
$$

2. If $R \geq R_{\mathcal{P}}+\varepsilon$, then

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { satisfies } \mathcal{P}\right] \geq 1-\binom{b}{2} \cdot\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{\varepsilon n}{2 b}}
$$

The technical core of the proof of Theorem 3.10 is the following proposition.
Proposition 6.1. Let $n \leq q$ with $q$ a prime power, and let $b \in \mathbb{N}$. Let $\mathcal{V} \in\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)^{n}$ be a $b$-local profile. Let $0 \leq R \leq 1$ and $\varepsilon>0$ such that

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) \leq-\varepsilon \cdot \operatorname{dim} U \cdot n
$$

for all $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right), U \neq\{0\}$. Let $\mathcal{C}=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k\right)$ where $k=R n$ and $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are identically and independently sampled uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}$. Assume that $q>k b$ and that $\varepsilon n \geq$ $2 b(b+1)$. Then,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { contains a nonzero } n \times b \text { matrix satisfying } \mathcal{V}\right] \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{\varepsilon n}{2 b}}
$$

We defer proving Proposition 6.1 to Section 7. We now show how this proposition implies Theorem 3.10.

Proof of Theorem 3.10 given Proposition 6.1.

## Reduction from RLCs to Random RS codes

We first prove Eq. (3). Fix $\mathcal{V}=\left(\mathcal{V}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{V}_{n}\right) \in \mathcal{F}$. By Lemma 4.5, there is some $W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash$ $\mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ such that $\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R_{\mathcal{V}}) \geq \Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)$ for all $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$.

Let $D=\operatorname{dim} W$ and fix a linear map $\varphi: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b-D}$ with $\operatorname{ker} \varphi=W$. Consider the $(b-D)$-local profile $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}=\left(\varphi\left(\mathcal{V}_{1}\right), \ldots, \varphi\left(\mathcal{V}_{n}\right)\right)$. Note that for $\mathcal{C}$ to contain $\mathcal{V}$ it must also contain $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}$. Indeed, suppose that $A \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}$ is a matrix in $\mathcal{C}$ satisfying $\mathcal{V}$. Consider the matrix $A^{\prime} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times(b-D)}$ whose rows are $\varphi\left(A_{1 *}\right), \ldots, \varphi\left(A_{n *}\right)$. Then it is straightforward to verify that $A^{\prime}$ satisfies $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}$. Furthermore, by linearity, $A^{\prime} \subseteq \mathcal{C}$.

We now claim that Proposition 6.1 can be applied to $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}$. Indeed, by the definition of $R_{\mathcal{P}}$ (Eq. (14)),

$$
R \leq R_{\mathcal{P}}-\varepsilon \leq R_{\mathcal{V}}-\varepsilon
$$

Thus, for all $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$, we have

$$
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R)=\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)-\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, W, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)-\varepsilon n(\operatorname{dim} U-D) \leq-\varepsilon n(\operatorname{dim} U-D)
$$

Therefore,

$$
\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right) \leq(1-R-\varepsilon) \cdot n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-D)
$$

Now, let $U^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b-D}\right)$ such that $U^{\prime} \neq\{0\}$, and let $U \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ such that $W \subseteq U$ and $\varphi(U)=U^{\prime}$, that is, $U=\varphi^{-1}\left(U^{\prime}\right)$. Note that $\operatorname{dim} U^{\prime}=\operatorname{dim} U-D$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}^{\prime}, U^{\prime}, R\right) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}^{\prime} \cap U^{\prime}\right)-(1-R) n \cdot \operatorname{dim} U^{\prime} \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\varphi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)\right)-(1-R) n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-D) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)\right)-(1-R) n \cdot(\operatorname{dim} U-D) \\
& =\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R)-\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R) \leq-\varepsilon \cdot \operatorname{dim} U^{\prime} \cdot n
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, Proposition 6.1 applies to $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C}\right. & \text { satisfies } \mathcal{V}] \leq \operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { satisfies } \mathcal{V}^{\prime}\right] \\
& \leq \operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { contains a nonzero } n \times b \text { matrix satisfying } \mathcal{V}^{\prime}\right] \\
& \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4(b-D))^{4(b-D)} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{-c n}{2(b-D)}} \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{c n}{2 b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (3) now follows from a union bound on all $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}$.

# Reduction from Random RS Codes to RLCs 

We turn to prove Eq. (4).
Fix $\mathcal{V} \in \mathcal{F}$ such that $R_{\mathcal{P}}=R_{\mathcal{V}}$. We assume without loss of generality that $\varepsilon=R-R_{\mathcal{V}}$. We shall prove that

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathcal{C} \text { contains } \mathcal{V}\right] \geq 1-\binom{b}{2} \cdot\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{c n}{2 b}}
$$

which implies Eq. (4). By Lemma 4.5, there exist $U \in \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ and $T \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right) \backslash \mathcal{L}_{\text {Dist }}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ such that

$$
U, T \in \operatorname{argmax}\left\{\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, *, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)\right\}
$$

We may assume that $T \subseteq U$, since Lemma 4.7 yields

$$
\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U \cap T, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right) \geq \Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)+\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, T, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)-\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U+T, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right) \geq \Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)
$$

where the second inequality is due to Eq. (26). Hence, $U \cap T \in \operatorname{argmax}\left\{\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, *, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)\right\}$ by virtue of Eq. (26).

Furthermore, we may assume that $U=\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ and $T=\{0\}$. We turn to justify this assumption. Write $U=T \oplus S$ for some linear subspace $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ satisfying $\operatorname{dim} S=\operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim} T$. Let $\pi: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b} \rightarrow S$ denote the projection map onto $S$ with regard to this direct sum. Let $\phi: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{\operatorname{dim} S} \rightarrow S$ be a linear bijection. Consider the profile $\mathcal{V}^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\operatorname{dim} S}\right)^{n}$ where $\mathcal{V}_{i}^{\prime}=\phi^{-1}\left(\pi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right)\right)$. Let $W^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\operatorname{dim} S}\right)$ and set $W=\phi\left(W^{\prime}\right)+T$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}^{\prime}, W^{\prime}, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}^{\prime} \cap W^{\prime}\right)-\left(1-R_{\mathcal{V}}\right) \operatorname{dim} W^{\prime} \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\pi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right) \cap \phi\left(W^{\prime}\right)\right)-\left(1-R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)(\operatorname{dim} W-\operatorname{dim} T) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\pi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right) \cap W\right)-\left(1-R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)(\operatorname{dim} W-\operatorname{dim} T) \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap T\right)\right)-\left(1-R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)(\operatorname{dim} W-\operatorname{dim} T) \\
& =\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, W, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)-\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, T, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The penultimate equality follows from the rank nullity theorem applied to the linear map $\pi$ and the vector space $\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W$, and the observation that $\pi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)=\pi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i}\right) \cap W$.

Observe that $\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, T, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)$ does not depend on $W^{\prime}$. Therefore, $\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}^{\prime}, W^{\prime}, R_{V}\right)$ is maximized when $W^{\prime}$ corresponds to a space $W \in \operatorname{argmax}\left\{\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, *, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)\right\}$. In particular $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\operatorname{dim} S}$ and $\{0\}$ correspond to $U$ and $T$, respectively. Thus, by Eq. (26), $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{\operatorname{dim} S},\{0\} \in \operatorname{argmax}\left\{\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}^{\prime}, *, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)\right\}$ and so by Corollary 4.6, $R_{\mathcal{V}^{\prime}}=R_{\mathcal{V}}$. If Eq. (25) applies to $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}$ then it also applies to $\mathcal{V}$ since, by linearity of $\mathcal{C}$, containing $\mathcal{V}$ implies containing $\mathcal{V}^{\prime}$. It therefore suffices to prove Eq. (25) under the assumption that $U=\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ and $T=\{0\}$. We proceed to do so.

Denote $K=\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}$. By Eq. (26),

$$
\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}, R\right)=\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)+\varepsilon \cdot n \cdot b=\Phi\left(\mathcal{V},\{0\}, R_{\mathcal{V}}\right)+\varepsilon \cdot n \cdot b=\varepsilon \cdot n \cdot b
$$

Thus, by Eq. (17), it holds deterministically that

$$
\operatorname{dim} K \geq \Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}, R\right)=d
$$

where $d=\lceil\varepsilon \cdot n \cdot b\rceil$.
Denote $U_{u, v}=\left\{x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b} \mid x_{u}=x_{v}\right\}$ and $K_{u, v}=\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U_{u, v}}^{*}$. Let $E_{u, v}$ denote the event that $\operatorname{dim} K_{u, v} \geq d$. We claim that if none of the events $E_{u, v}$ hold then $\mathcal{C}$ contains $\mathcal{V}$. Indeed, assume that no event $E_{u, v}$ holds. Note that

$$
\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap M_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}=K \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}=K \backslash\left(\bigcup_{u, v} K_{u, v}\right)
$$

Hence,

$$
\left|\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap M_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }}\right| \geq|K|-\sum_{u, v}\left|K_{u, v}\right| \geq q^{d}-\binom{b}{2} \cdot q^{d-1}>0
$$

where the last inequality is by our assumption that $q>k b \geq \varepsilon n b \geq 2 b^{2}(b+1)$. Consequently,

$$
\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap M_{\mathcal{V}}^{\text {Dist }} \neq \emptyset
$$

so $\mathcal{C}$ contains $\mathcal{V}$ and thus satisfies $\mathcal{P}$.
We turn to bound the probability of $E_{u, v}$ for some fixed $u, v$. To this end, we find a necessary condition for this event. Let $\mathcal{D}=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k-t\right)$, where $t=\left\lfloor\frac{d-1}{b-1}\right\rfloor$. Observe that $\mathcal{D}$ is a linear subspace of $\mathcal{C}$ of codimension $t$. Moreover, $\mathcal{D}^{b} \cap \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times U_{u, v}}$ is a subspace of $\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times U_{u, v}}$, with codimension $t \cdot \operatorname{dim} U_{u, v}=t \cdot(b-1)$. Therefore,

$$
\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{D}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U_{u, v}}^{*}\right) \geq \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{C}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U_{u, v}}^{*}\right)-t(b-1)=\operatorname{dim} K_{u, v}-t(b-1)
$$

Therefore, the event $E_{u, v}$ implies that $\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{D}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U_{u, v}}^{*}\right) \geq 1$. We next bound the probability of the latter.

Let $\psi: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b-1}$ be the projection map onto the coordinate set $[b] \backslash\{u\}$. Define the $(b-1)$-local profile $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b-1}\right)^{n}$ by $\mathcal{T}_{i}=\psi\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U_{u, v}\right)$. Note that $\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{D}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U_{u, v}}^{*}\right)=\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{D}^{b-1} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{T}}\right)$. Moreover, let $W^{\prime} \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b-1}\right)$ and let $W \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)$ such that $W \subseteq U_{u, v}$ and $\psi(W)=W^{\prime}$. Then, denoting $\delta=\frac{t}{n}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi\left(\mathcal{T}, W^{\prime}, R_{\mathcal{V}}-\delta\right) & =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{T}_{i} \cap W^{\prime}\right)-\left(1-\left(R_{\mathcal{V}}-\delta\right)\right) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} W^{\prime} \\
& =\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap W\right)-\left(1-\left(R_{\mathcal{V}}-\delta\right)\right) \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} W \\
& =\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R_{\mathcal{V}}-\delta)=\Phi(\mathcal{V}, W, R_{\mathcal{V}})-\delta \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} W \\
& \leq \Phi(\mathcal{V},\{0\}, R_{\mathcal{V}})-\delta \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} W \leq-\delta \cdot n \cdot \operatorname{dim} W
\end{aligned}
$$

where the first inequality is due to Eq. (26). Hence, Proposition 6.1 yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}\left[E_{u, v}\right] \leq \operatorname{Pr}\left[\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{D}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{V}, U_{u, v}}^{*}\right) \geq 1\right]=\operatorname{Pr}\left[\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{D}^{b} \cap \mathcal{M}_{\mathcal{T}}\right) \geq 1\right] & \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b}(k-t)}{\delta q}\right)^{\frac{\delta n}{2 b}} \\
& \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{\varepsilon n}{2 b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (25) follows since

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[\mathcal{C} \text { contains } \mathcal{V}] \geq 1-\operatorname{Pr}\left[\bigcup_{u, v} E_{u, v}\right] \geq 1-\binom{b}{2} \cdot\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} k}{\varepsilon q}\right)^{\frac{\varepsilon n}{2 b}}
$$

# 7 On local profiles in a random RS code-Proof of Proposition 6.1 

In this section we prove Proposition 6.1. Our first step is to extend the notion of a local profile, defining what we term a local polynomial profile.

### 7.1 Local Polynomial Profiles

We require some notation. Fix $a \in \mathbb{N}$. A tuple of polynomials $\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{a}\right) \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a}$ is said to be $k$-bounded if $\operatorname{deg}\left(P_{i}\right)<k$ for every $1 \leq i \leq a$. We denote the set of all $k$-bounded tuples by

$$
Q_{k, a}=\left\{\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{a}\right) \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a} \mid \forall 1 \leq i \leq a, \quad \operatorname{deg}\left(P_{i}\right)<k\right\}
$$

Observe that $Q_{k, a}$ is an $F_{q}$-linear space. If $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a}$ consists of $k$-bounded tuples, we say that $S$ itself is $k$-bounded.

For $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ and $\boldsymbol{P}=\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{a}\right) \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a}$, we denote the evaluation $\boldsymbol{P}(\alpha):=\left(P_{1}(\alpha), \ldots, P_{a}(\alpha)\right)$. For $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a}$, we denote $S(\alpha):=\{\boldsymbol{P}(\alpha) \mid \boldsymbol{P} \in S\}$. If $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{m \times m^{\prime}}$ is a matrix of polynomials, let $A(\alpha) \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{m \times m^{\prime}}$ denote the entry-wise evaluation matrix of $A$ on $\alpha$.

Let $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$ denote the field of univariate rational functions over $\mathbb{F}_{q}$. We naturally embed $\mathbb{F}_{q}$ in $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$ by considering each $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ as the constant rational function $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$. By abuse of notation, both objects will be denoted by $\alpha$. Note that every $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space is also $F_{q^{-}}$ linear. Throughout this section we use dim and Dim to refer to linear dimension of $\mathbb{F}_{q}$ and $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$, respectively. We similarly distinguish between span and Span, and between rank and Rank. Observe that the space $Q_{k, a}$ is $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear but not $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear.

The following fact will be useful.
Lemma 7.1 (Dimension of $S(\alpha)$ ). Let $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ be an $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space and write $D=\operatorname{DimSpan} S$. The following now holds:

1. $\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha) \leq D$ for every $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$.
2. If $S$ is $k$-bounded $(k \in \mathbb{N})$ then

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha \sim \mathbf{U}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}\right)}[\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha)=D] \geq 1-\frac{D k}{q}
$$

Proof. Let $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{[S] \times b}$ be a matrix (possibly with infinitely many rows) whose rows are the elements of $S$. Denote $t:=\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha)=\operatorname{rank} A(\alpha)$. Note that $A$ contains a minor $M \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{t \times t}$ such that $\operatorname{rank} M(\alpha)=t$. Thus,

$$
(\operatorname{det} M)(\alpha)=\operatorname{det}(M(\alpha)) \neq 0
$$

implying that $\operatorname{det} M$ is a non-zero polynomial, so $M$ has full rank over $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$. Thus,

$$
D=\operatorname{Rank} A \geq \operatorname{Rank} M=t=\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha)
$$

The first claim follows.
We turn to the second claim. Suppose that $S$ is $k$-bounded. Let $M^{\prime} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{D \times D}$ be a minor of $A$ with Rank $M^{\prime}=D$, so $\operatorname{det} M^{\prime} \neq 0$. Since the entries of $M^{\prime}$ are polynomials of degree at most

$k$, the non-zero polynomial $\operatorname{det} M^{\prime}$ has degree at most $D k$. Hence, a uniformly random $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ satisfies $\left(\operatorname{det} M^{\prime}\right)(\alpha) \neq 0$ with probability at least $1-\frac{D k}{q}$. Suppose that this event holds. Then,

$$
D \geq t=\operatorname{rank} A(\alpha) \geq \operatorname{rank} M^{\prime}(\alpha) \geq D
$$

so $\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha)=t=D$.
We turn to define the notion of a local polynomial profile.
Definition 7.2. An $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear map $\psi: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a}$ is said to be polynomial if $\psi\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}\right) \subseteq$ $\mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a}$. In other words, $\psi$ is polynomial if it is represented in the standard basis by a matrix with polynomial entries. We use $\operatorname{deg} \psi$ to denote the maximum degree (as a polynomial) of an entry in this matrix.

Definition 7.3. A b-local polynomial profile is a sequence $\Psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots \psi_{n}\right)$ of $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear polynomial maps $\psi_{i}: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b_{i}}$ (for some $b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n} \in \mathbb{N}$ ). We denote $\operatorname{deg} \Psi=\max _{1 \leq i \leq n} \operatorname{deg} \psi_{i}$.

Let $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$. A tuple of polynomials $\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{b}\right)$ is said to satisfy $(\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha})$ if for every $i \in[n]$ it holds that

$$
\left(\psi_{i}\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{b}\right)\right)\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=0
$$

For an $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$, we denote

$$
S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]=\{\boldsymbol{P} \in S \mid \boldsymbol{P} \text { satisfies }(\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha})\}
$$

Note that $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$ is an $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space.
Polynomial profiles provide a framework for directly analyzing and manipulating message vectors, which, in the case of random RS codes, correspond to the coefficient vectors of low-degree polynomials. This generalization enables one to define profiles that are well-suited for the stochastic process to proceed until completion (see Section 7.4 for further details). Additionally, we require a notion that is related to the concept of $\Phi$, which is defined for subspaces of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$.

Definition 7.4 (Strength). For an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ and a polynomial map $\psi$, we denote $\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\psi):=\operatorname{Dim} \psi(U)$. Note that when $U=\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$, we have $\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\psi)=\operatorname{Rank} \psi$.

For an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ and a polynomial profile $\Psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots \psi_{n}\right)$, we denote $\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{strength}_{U}\left(\psi_{i}\right)$.

Definition 7.5. Given $T, U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$, where $U$ is an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace, we say that $U$ is $T$-live if $\operatorname{Span}(T \cap U)=U$. Otherwise, we say that $U$ is $T$-dead.

Our goal is to rephrase Proposition 6.1 in terms of local polynomial profiles. We require the following lemma to do so.

Lemma 7.6. Let $n \leq q$ with $q$ a prime power. Let $\mathcal{V}=\left(V_{1}, \ldots, V_{n}\right) \in\left(\mathcal{L}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}\right)\right)^{n}$ be a b-local profile. Then, there exists a b-local polynomial profile $\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}$ with $\operatorname{deg}\left(\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}\right)=0$ such that, for every $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right) \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ and $k \in \mathbb{N}$, the following holds:

$$
\operatorname{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k\right) \text { contains a nonzero } n \times b \text { matrix satisfying } \mathcal{V} \quad \Rightarrow \quad \operatorname{dim} Q_{k, b}\left[\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}\right]>0
$$

Furthermore, for every $Q_{k, b}$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ there exists an $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space $U^{\prime} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ with $\operatorname{Dim} U=\operatorname{dim} U^{\prime}$ and

$$
\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi) \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{Dim} U-\operatorname{dim}\left(U^{\prime} \cap V_{i}\right)\right)
$$

Proof. For $1 \leq i \leq n$, let $\varphi_{i}: \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b-\operatorname{dim} V_{i}}$ be an $F_{q}$-linear map with $\operatorname{ker} \varphi_{i}=V_{i}$. Take $\psi_{i}: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b-\operatorname{dim} V_{i}}$ to be an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear map whose restriction to $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ is $\varphi_{i}$. In other words, the matrix representation of $\psi_{i}$ in the standard basis is the same as that of $\varphi_{i}$. In particular, $\operatorname{deg} \psi_{i}=0$. Observe that $\varphi_{i}(\boldsymbol{P}(\alpha))=\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{P})(\alpha)$ for all $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ and $\boldsymbol{P} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$. Finally, take $\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$ and note that $\operatorname{deg} \Psi_{\mathcal{V}}=0$.

Now, suppose that $\mathcal{C}:=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k\right)$ contains a non zero matrix $A \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n \times b}$ that satisfies $\mathcal{V}$. By definition of the RS code, there is a tuple of distinct polynomials $\mathbf{0} \neq \boldsymbol{P}:=\left(P_{1}, \ldots, P_{b}\right) \in Q_{k, b}$ such that $A_{i, j}=P_{j}\left(\alpha_{i}\right)$ for all $1 \leq i \leq n$ and $1 \leq j \leq b$. Observe that $\boldsymbol{P}$ satisfies $\left(\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}\right)$. Indeed,

$$
\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{P})\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=\varphi_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{P}\left(\alpha_{i}\right)\right)=\varphi_{i}\left(A_{i *}\right)=0
$$

since $A_{i *} \in V_{i}=\operatorname{ker} \varphi_{i}$. Therefore, $\boldsymbol{P} \in Q_{k, b}\left[\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}\right]$, and thus $\operatorname{dim} Q_{k, b}[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]>0$.
We turn to proving the last part of the lemma. Let $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ be $Q_{k, b}$-live and denote $D=\operatorname{Dim} U$. Let $S=Q_{k, b} \cap U$. Note that $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ is an $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space and is $k$-bounded, and therefore by the second item of Lemma 7.1,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha \sim \cup\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}\right)}[\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha)=D] \geq 1-\frac{D k}{q} \geq 1-\frac{b k}{q}>0
$$

In particular, we may fix some $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ such that $\operatorname{dim} S(\alpha)=D$. We take $U^{\prime}=S(\alpha)$. It remains to show that $U^{\prime}$ satisfies Eq. (29).

Fix $1 \leq i \leq n$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{dim}\left(U^{\prime} \cap V_{i}\right) & =D-\operatorname{dim} \varphi_{i}\left(U^{\prime}\right) \\
& =D-\operatorname{dim}\left\{\varphi_{i}(\boldsymbol{P}(\alpha)) \mid \boldsymbol{P} \in S\right\} \\
& =D-\operatorname{dim}\left\{\psi_{i}(\boldsymbol{P})(\alpha) \mid \boldsymbol{P} \in S\right\} \\
& \geq D-\operatorname{Dim}\left(\operatorname{Span} \psi_{i}(S)\right) \\
& \geq D-\operatorname{Dim} \psi_{i}(U)
\end{aligned}
$$

The first inequality above follows from the first item of Lemma 7.1, and the second holds because $U$ is $Q_{k, b}$-live. Hence,

$$
\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{Dim} \psi_{i}(U) \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(D-\operatorname{dim}\left(U^{\prime} \cap V_{i}\right)\right)
$$

We give some intuition for strength. Recall that for $U, U^{\prime}$ as defined in the previous lemma, we have $D=\operatorname{Dim} U=\operatorname{dim} U^{\prime}$. By Eq. (29), we see that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Phi(\mathcal{V}, U, R) & =\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)-(1-R) n \operatorname{dim} U \\
& =-\left(\sum_{i} \operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{dim}\left(\mathcal{V}_{i} \cap U\right)\right)+R n \operatorname{dim} U \\
& \leq R n \operatorname{dim} U-\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi)
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, we observe a close relationship between $\Phi$ and strength. The following lemma, which facilitates the transition to working exclusively with $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear structures, makes this connection more explicit.
Lemma 7.7. Fix a prime power $q$ and let $k, b \in \mathbb{N}$. Let $\Psi$ be a b-local polynomial profile with $\operatorname{deg}(\Psi)=0$. Suppose that there exists $\lambda \geq 2 b(b+1)$ such that for every $Q_{k, b}$-live $F_{q}(X)$-linear space $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ with $U \neq\{0\}$, there holds

$$
\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi) \geq(k+\lambda) \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U
$$

Then,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\operatorname{dim} Q_{k, b}[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]>0\right] \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 b+1} \cdot k \cdot n}{\lambda \cdot q}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 b}}
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\alpha}$ is sampled uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$.
Before proving Lemma 7.7, we show that it implies Proposition 6.1.
Proof of Proposition 6.1 given Lemma 7.7. Let $\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}$ be as in Lemma 7.6. Take $\lambda=\varepsilon \cdot n$. Let $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ be a $Q_{k, b}$-live non-trivial $F_{q}(X)$-linear space and let $U^{\prime} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{b}$ be a corresponding $F_{q}$-linear space satisfying Eq. $$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{strength}_{U}\left(\Psi_{\mathcal{V}}\right) & \geq \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left(\operatorname{Dim} U-\operatorname{dim}\left(U^{\prime} \cap V_{i}\right)\right) \\
& =n \cdot\left(\operatorname{Dim} U-\operatorname{dim} U^{\prime}\right)+k \cdot \operatorname{dim} U^{\prime}-\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U^{\prime}, R\right) \\
& =k \cdot \operatorname{dim} U^{\prime}-\Phi\left(\mathcal{V}, U^{\prime}, R\right) \\
& \geq(k+\varepsilon \cdot n) \cdot \operatorname{dim} U^{\prime} \\
& =(k+\lambda) \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, by Eq. (28) and Lemma 7.7,
$\operatorname{Pr}\left[\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} ; k\right)\right.$ contains a nonzero $n \times b$ matrix satisfying $\mathcal{V}] \leq \operatorname{Pr}\left[\operatorname{dim} Q_{k, b}(\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha})>0\right]$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} \cdot k \cdot n}{\lambda \cdot q}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 b}} \\
& =\left(2^{b}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(4 b)^{4 b} \cdot k}{\varepsilon \cdot q}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 b}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The rest of this section is devoted to proving Lemma 7.7. The main ingredient in our proof is a potential function, which we now define.

# 7.2 A Potential Function for Local Polynomial Profiles 

Let $\Psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$ be a $b$-local polynomial profile and let $\boldsymbol{\alpha}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right)$ be a uniformly random element of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$. To prove Lemma 7.7 we need to bound the probability that $Q_{k, b}[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \supseteq\{\mathbf{0}\}$. To this end, we will tackle a more general question: given a finite $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$, how likely is it that $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \supseteq\{\mathbf{0}\}$ ? To help answer this question, we define a potential function $\Pi$. Given an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space $W \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$, we denote

$$
d_{W}(S):=\operatorname{dim}(S \cap W)
$$

and

$$
\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi):=d_{W}(S)-\operatorname{strength}_{W}(\Psi)
$$

To motivate our definition of $\Pi_{W}$, consider an iterative stochastic process in which the random evaluation points $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are revealed one by one. For $0 \leq i \leq n$, denote $\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i}=\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i}\right)$. Also, $\Psi_{1 \cdots i}=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{i}\right)$ and $\Psi_{i \cdots n}=\left(\psi_{i}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$. Note that $S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i}\right]$ is fully known after the $i$-th step of the stochastic process. Moreover,

$$
S=S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots 0}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots 0}\right] \supseteq S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots 1}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots 1}\right] \supseteq \cdots \supseteq S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots n}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots n}\right]=S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]
$$

As we show below (Lemma 7.9), the decrease in dimension in a single step, namely, $d_{W}\left(S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i-1}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i-1}\right]\right)-d_{W}\left(S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i}\right]\right)$, is at most $\operatorname{Dim} \psi_{i}(W)$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
d_{W}(S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]) & =d_{W}(S)-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} d_{W}\left(S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i-1}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i-1}\right]\right)-d_{W}\left(S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i}\right]\right)\right) \\
& \geq d_{W}(S)-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} \operatorname{Dim} \psi_{i}(W)\right) \\
& =d_{W}(S)-\operatorname{strength}_{W}(\Psi)=\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi))
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, if $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ is positive then $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \cap W$ is guaranteed to have positive dimension, implying, in particular, that $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \supseteq\{0\}$.

We turn to the examine the opposite case, namely, when $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ is very negative (that is, much smaller than zero). Suppose that $\boldsymbol{\alpha}$ is sampled uniformly at random from $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$. One may hope to show that $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \cap W=\{0\}$ holds in this setting with high probability. However, this is not always true. Indeed, a construction along the lines of Example 4.2 yields a setting in which $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ is very negative, but $\Pi_{W^{\prime}}(S, \Psi)$ is positive for some nontrivial $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace $W^{\prime} \subseteq W$. By Eq. (31), we then have $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \cap W \supseteq S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \cap W^{\prime} \supseteq\{0\}$.

In Lemma 7.8 we manage to show that a somewhat weaker probabilistic phenomenon does always occur whenever $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ is very negative. Namely, we show that $W$ is $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$-dead with very high probability.
Lemma 7.8 (If $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ is very negative then $W$ is probably $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$-dead). Let $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ be a $k$-bounded $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space $(k \in \mathbb{N})$. Let $\Psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$ be a $b$-local polynomial profile and let $g=\operatorname{deg} \Psi$. Let $W \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ be an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space and let $D=\operatorname{Dim} W$. Let $L>0$ and suppose that $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi) \leq-L$. Then,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha} \sim 0\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}\right)}[W \text { is } S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \text {-live }] \leq\left(\begin{array}{c}
n \\
{\left\lceil\frac{L}{D}\right\rceil}
\end{array}\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(k+g) D}{q}\right)^{\left\lceil\frac{L}{D}\right\rceil}
$$

Furthermore, let $0 \leq L^{\prime} \leq L$ and let $E_{L^{\prime}}$ denote the event that at least one of the following occurs:

- $W$ is $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$-live OR
- Let $0 \leq s \leq n$ denote the minimum index for which $W$ is $S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots s}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots s}\right]$-dead. Also, $\Pi_{W}\left(S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots s}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots s}\right], \Psi_{s+1 \cdots n}\right) \geq-L^{\prime}$ holds.

Then, for all $0 \leq L^{\prime} \leq L$,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha} \sim \mathbf{U}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}\right)}\left[E_{L^{\prime}}\right] \leq\binom{n}{\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D}\right\rceil} \cdot\left(\frac{(k+g) D}{q}\right)^{\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D}\right\rceil}
$$

We prove Lemma 7.8 in the following section.

# 7.3 If $\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ is Very Negative Then $W$ is Probably $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$-Dead — Proof of Lemma 7.8 

Let $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ be an $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space. Recall that for $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ we denote $S(\alpha):=\{\boldsymbol{P}(\alpha) \mid \boldsymbol{P} \in S\}$. We require a key observation about the evaluation map $S \rightarrow S(\alpha)$. We require the following lemma in order to prove Lemma 7.8.

Lemma 7.9 (The change in $\Pi_{W}$ in a single step). Let $\Psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$ be a b-local polynomial profile, let $S \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ be a $k$-bounded $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space $(k \in \mathbb{N})$. Let $W \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ be an $S$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space.

Given $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$, write $p=\Pi_{W}(S, \Psi)$ and $p_{\alpha}=\Pi_{W}\left(S\left[\psi_{1}, \alpha\right], \Psi_{2 \cdots n}\right)$. Also, let $D=\operatorname{Dim} \psi_{1}(W)$ and $g=\operatorname{deg} \psi_{1}$.

Then,

$$
p \leq p_{\alpha} \leq p+D
$$

for all $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$. Furthermore,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha \sim \mathbf{U}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}\right)}\left[p_{\alpha}=p\right] \geq 1-\frac{(k+g) \cdot D}{q}
$$

Proof. Denote

$$
t_{\alpha}:=\operatorname{dim}(W \cap S)-\operatorname{dim}\left(W \cap S\left[\psi_{1}, \alpha\right]\right)=\operatorname{dim}\left(\psi_{1}(W \cap S)(\alpha)\right)
$$

Observe that

$$
p_{\alpha}=p-t_{\alpha}+D
$$

Since $\operatorname{Span}(W \cap S)=W$, we also have

$$
\operatorname{Dim} \operatorname{Span}\left(\psi_{1}(W \cap S)\right)=\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{1}(W)\right)=D
$$

Observe that every tuple in $\psi_{1}(W \cap S)$ is $(g+k)$-bounded. Hence, applying Lemma 7.1 to the space $\psi_{1}(W \cap S)$ yields $0 \leq t_{\alpha} \leq D$ for all $\alpha$, and $\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha \sim \mathbf{U}\left(\mathbb{F}_{q}\right)}\left[t_{\alpha}=D\right] \geq 1-\frac{D \cdot(g+k)}{q}$.

We can now prove Lemma 7.8.
Proof of Lemma 7.8. It suffices to prove Eq. (33), since the latter implies Eq. (32) by taking $L^{\prime}=0$. We turn to prove Eq. (33). Let $\boldsymbol{\alpha}$ be uniformly sampled from $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$. For $0 \leq i \leq n$ denote $S_{i}=S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i}\right]$ and $p_{i}=\Pi_{W}\left(S_{i}, \Psi_{i+1 \cdots n}\right)$. Recall that $p_{0}=-L$.

Observe that the bad event $E_{L^{\prime}}$ implies that there is some $1 \leq t \leq n$ such that $W$ is $S_{t-1}$-live and $p_{t} \geq-L^{\prime}$. Indeed, suppose that $E_{L^{\prime}}$ holds and consider two cases. If $W$ is $S_{n}$-dead, then taking $t=s$ (recall that $s$ is the minimum index for which $W$ is $S_{s}$-dead) satisfies the claim. Otherwise, take $t=n$. Since $W$ is $S_{n}$-live it is also $S_{n-1}$-live. Now,

$$
p_{t}=p_{n}=\operatorname{dim}\left(W \cap S_{n}\right) \geq 0 \geq-L^{\prime}
$$

and the claim holds. Therefore,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[E_{L^{\prime}}\right] \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[p_{t} \geq-L^{\prime}\right]
$$

Let

$$
M=\left\{i \in[n] \mid p_{i+1}>p_{i}\right\}
$$

namely, $M$ is the set of steps in which the potential function strictly increases. By the first part of Lemma 7.9, each step in $M$ increases the potential by at most $D$. Hence,

$$
p_{t} \leq p_{0}+D \cdot|M \cap[t]|=-L+D \cdot|M \cap[t]|
$$

Thus, a necessary event for $p_{t} \geq-L^{\prime}$ is that $|M \cap[t]| \geq m$, where $m=\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D}\right\rceil$. For $0 \leq i \leq n$, let $G_{i}$ denote the event that $W$ is $S_{i}$-live (note that $G_{i}$ implies $\left.G_{0}, \ldots, G_{i-1}\right)$. Note that the events $G_{0}, \ldots, G_{t-1}$ hold by definition of $t$. Thus, taking $I=M \cap[t]$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[E_{L^{\prime}}\right] \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[p_{t} \geq-L^{\prime}\right] & \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\bigvee_{[I \subseteq[n]}\right. \text { [I] }=m}(I \subseteq M) \wedge G_{\max I-1}\right] \\
& \leq \sum_{\substack{I \subseteq[n] \\
|I|=m}} \operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha_{1}, \ldots \alpha_{\max I}}\left[(I \subseteq M) \wedge G_{\max I-1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The sum on the right-hand side has $\binom{n}{m}$ terms. To prove Eq. (33), it suffices to show that each of these terms is at most $\left(\frac{(k+q) D}{q}\right)^{m}$. We proceed to do so.

Fix $I \subseteq[n]$ with $|I|=m$. Write $I=\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{m}\right\}$ where $i_{1}<i_{2}<\cdots<i_{m}$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha_{1}, \ldots \alpha_{i_{m}}}\left[I \subseteq M \wedge G_{i_{m}-1}\right] & =\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha_{1}, \ldots \alpha_{i_{m}}}\left[(I \subseteq M) \wedge G_{0} \wedge G_{1} \wedge \cdots \wedge G_{i_{m}-1}\right] \\
& \leq \prod_{j=1}^{m} \operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{j}}}\left[i_{j} \in M \mid\left(\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{j-1}\right\} \subseteq M\right) \wedge G_{i_{j}-1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

The inequality follows from the fact that $G_{i}$ implies $G_{0} \wedge \ldots \wedge G_{i-1}$. To finish the proof we show that each term on the right-hand side is at most $\frac{(k+q) D}{q}$. Let $1 \leq j \leq m$.

Condition on $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{j}-1}$ for which $\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{j-1}\right\} \subseteq M \wedge G_{i_{j}-1}$ holds. In particular, under this conditioning, $S_{i_{j}-1}$ is determined and satisfies $\operatorname{Span}\left(S_{i_{j}-1} \cap W\right)=W$. Furthermore, recall that $i_{j} \in M$ is the event where the potential function increases after substituting a random $\alpha_{i_{j}}$. Thus, for all $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{j}-1}$ for which $\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{j-1}\right\} \subseteq M \wedge G_{i_{j}-1}$ holds, by the second part of Lemma 7.9, we have

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{j}}}\left[i_{j} \in M \mid \alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{j}-1}\right] \leq \frac{(k+g) D}{q}
$$

Because the events $\left\{i_{1}, \ldots, i_{j-1}\right\} \subseteq M$ and $G_{i_{j}-1}$ only depend on $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{i_{j}-1}$, we see that the $j$-th term in the product above is at most $\frac{(k+g) D}{q}$.

# 7.4 If $\Pi_{U}(S, \Psi)$ is Very Negative for All $U$ Then $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$ is Probably Trivial 

In this section, we prove a stronger version of Lemma 7.8, which directly implies Lemma 7.7.
Lemma 7.10 (If $\Pi_{U}(S, \Psi)$ is very negative for all $U$ then $S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$ is probably trivial). Let $S \subseteq$ $\mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ be a $k$-bounded $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear space $(k \in \mathbb{N})$. Let $W=\operatorname{Span} S$ and write $D_{W}=\operatorname{Dim} W$. Let $\Psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \ldots, \psi_{n}\right)$ be a b-local polynomial profile and denote $g:=\max \{\operatorname{deg} \Psi, b \cdot k\}$. Suppose that there exists some

$$
\lambda \geq 2 \cdot D_{W} \cdot\left(D_{W}+1\right)
$$

such that

$$
\Pi_{U}(S, \Psi) \leq-\lambda \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U
$$

for every $S$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace $U \subseteq W$. Then,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}[S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}] \supseteq\{0\}] \leq\left(2^{D_{W}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W}} \cdot g \cdot n}{\lambda \cdot q}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}}
$$

Proof of Lemma 7.7 given Lemma 7.10. The claim follows by applying Lemma 7.10 to $S:=Q_{k, b}$ and $\Psi$. Note that $g=b \cdot k$. Also, Eq. (30) yields

$$
\Pi_{U}(S, \Psi)=\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap Q_{k, b}\right)-\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi) \leq k \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U-\operatorname{strength}_{U}(\Psi) \leq-\lambda \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U
$$

for every $Q_{k, b}$-live $U \subseteq W$. The first inequality, $\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap Q_{k, b}\right) \leq k \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U$, follows from the following argument. Let $G \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b \times \operatorname{Dim} U}$ be a generating matrix for $U$ in systematic form, namely, $U=\left(G x \mid x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{\operatorname{Dim} U}\right)$. Therefore, $G$ contains a $\operatorname{Dim} U \times \operatorname{Dim} U$ identity matrix as a sub-matrix. Due to the systematic form of $G$, we have

$$
U \cap Q_{k, b} \subseteq\left(G x \mid x \in Q_{k, \operatorname{Dim} U}\right)
$$

Thus,

$$
\left|U \cap Q_{k, b}\right| \leq\left|Q_{k, \operatorname{Dim} U}\right|=q^{k \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U}
$$

and so,

$$
\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap Q_{k, b}\right)=\log _{q}\left|U \cap Q_{k, b}\right| \leq k \cdot \operatorname{Dim} U
$$

One may attempt to prove Lemma 7.10 by the following straighforward approach. Denote $S_{n}=S[\Psi, \boldsymbol{\alpha}]$. An equivalent condition for $S_{n}=\{0\}$, is that every $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space $U \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ is $S_{n}$-dead. Eq. (34) and Lemma 7.8 imply that this is very likely for any given $U$, so it seems reasonable to attempt a union bound over all $S$-live subspaces $U$ (an analogous union bound over subspaces is inherent to our proof of Proposition 4.3). Unfortunately, the number of $S$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$ linear subspaces (roughly $q^{\Omega\left(k \cdot k^{2}\right)}$ ) is too large for this approach to work. Therefore, we require a subtler strategy.

In our proof of Lemma 7.10, we follow the run of the iterative stochastic process described at the opening of this subsection. We run the process until a time $s$ in which one of two stopping conditions occurs. The first condition is that the space $W$ (namely, the $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-span of $S$ ) is $S_{s}$-dead, at which point we continue the run with regard to $S_{s}$, whose $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-span is now smaller. This is the simple case.

The second stopping condition is that some $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-subspace $U \subseteq W$ has become "worrisome". By this, we mean that $p_{U, s}:=\Pi_{U}\left(S_{s}, \Psi_{s+1 \cdots n}\right)$ has increased and gotten too close to zero from the negative side. This is indeed worrying since, if this potential becomes positive, it is guaranteed that $S_{n} \cap U \neq\{0\}$, so we cannot hope to have $S_{n}=\{0\}$. In this case, we proceed recursively by analyzing two different runs. First, we consider the set $S_{s} \cap U$ and show the remaining negative potential $p_{U, t}$ is still negative enough to ensure that $S_{n} \cap U=\{0\}$ with high probability. Second, we define a "quotient set" $S / U$ and "quotient profile" $\Psi / U$. Using the fact that $p_{U, s}$ is only slightly negative, we show that this quotient run likely leads to the $\{0\}$-set, meaning that $S_{n} \subseteq U$ is likely. Together, $S_{n} \cap U=\{0\}$ and $S_{n} \subseteq U$ imply that $S_{n}=\{0\}$.

Proof of Lemma 7.10. Throughout this proof, if $U$ is an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space, we denote $D_{U}=$ $\operatorname{Dim} U$. We prove the claim by induction on $D_{W}$. The case $D_{W}=0$ is immediate. Suppose that $D_{W} \geq 1$. Write $L=\lambda \cdot D_{W}$ and let $L^{\prime}=\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{W}$, where

$$
\lambda^{*}=\left\lceil\frac{\left(D_{W}-1\right) \cdot \lambda}{D_{W}}+D_{W}\right\rceil
$$

Let $\boldsymbol{\alpha}$ be sampled uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$. For $0 \leq i \leq n$, denote $S_{i}=S\left[\Psi_{1 \cdots i}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}_{1 \cdots i}\right]$ and $p_{U, i}=$ $\Pi_{U}\left(S_{i}, \Psi_{i+1 \cdots n}\right)$ (where $U \subseteq W$ is $F_{q}(X)$-linear).

Let $1 \leq t$ denote the minimal index at which $W$ is $S_{t}$-dead (if such an index does not exist, let $t=\infty)$. Let $F$ denote the event that $t<\infty$ and $p_{W, t}<-L^{\prime}$.

Let $1 \leq s$ denote the minimal index in which at least one of the following two events occur:

1. $W$ is $S_{s}$-dead OR
2. For some $S_{s}$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space $\{0\} \neq U \subsetneq W$, there holds

$$
p_{U, s}>-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{U}
$$

Let $F^{\prime}$ denote the event that $s<\infty$ and $p_{W, s}<-L^{\prime}$. Observe that $F$ implies $F^{\prime}$. Indeed, assume that $F$ holds. Clearly, $s \leq t$, so $s<\infty$. By Lemma $7.9, p_{W, 0}, \ldots, p_{W, n}$ is non-decreasing, so

$p_{W, s} \leq p_{W, t}<-L^{\prime}$, implying $F^{\prime}$. Therefore, by Lemma 7.8,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\overline{F^{\prime}}\right] \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}[\bar{F}] & \leq\left(\frac{n}{\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D_{W}}\right\rceil}\right) \cdot\left(\frac{(k+\operatorname{deg} \Psi) \cdot D_{W}}{q}\right)^{\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D_{W}}\right\rceil} \\
& \leq\left(\frac{n}{\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D_{W}}\right\rceil}\right) \cdot\left(\frac{2 g \cdot D_{W}}{q}\right)^{\left\lceil\frac{L-L^{\prime}}{D_{W}}\right\rceil} \\
& =\binom{n}{\left\lceil\lambda-\lambda^{*}\right\rceil} \cdot\left(\frac{2 g \cdot D_{W}}{q}\right)^{\left\lceil\lambda-\lambda^{*}\right\rceil} \\
& \leq\left(\frac{2 e \cdot n \cdot g \cdot D_{W}}{\left(\left\lceil\lambda-\lambda^{*}\right\rceil\right) q}\right)^{\left\lceil\lambda-\lambda^{*}\right\rceil} \\
& \leq\left(\frac{4 e \cdot n \cdot g \cdot D_{W}^{2}}{\lambda q}\right)^{\left\lceil\lambda-\lambda^{*}\right\rceil} \quad \text { by Eqs. (34) and (36) } \\
& \leq\left(\frac{4 e \cdot n \cdot g \cdot D_{W}^{2}}{\lambda q}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}} \quad \text { by Eq. (36) } \\
& \leq\left(\frac{4 e \cdot n \cdot g \cdot D_{W}^{2}}{\lambda q}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

We will show that, given $F^{\prime}$, the event $S_{n}=\{0\}$ is highly likely. This statement, combined with Eq. (38), will complete the proof.

Henceforth, we condition on the event $F^{\prime}$. Note that $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{s}$ fully determine $F^{\prime}$ and $s$. Therefore, the evaluation points $\alpha_{s+1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are unaffected by this conditioning and remain uniformly distributed and independent.

We will assume that $S_{s} \neq\{0\}$, because otherwise $S_{n} \subseteq S_{s}=\{0\}$, and we are done. We select an $S_{s}$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace $U \subsetneq W$ as follows. If $W$ is $S_{s}$-dead, we set $U=\operatorname{Span} S_{s}$. Otherwise, by our assumption of $F^{\prime}$ and definition of $s$, there exists an $S_{s}$-live subspace $\{0\} \neq U \subsetneq W$ with $p_{U, s}>-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{U}$. We then take $U$ to be some inclusion-maximal subspace with this property. Note that in either case, $U \neq\{0\}$ and therefore $\operatorname{Dim} U \geq 1$.

We now consider two events: $S_{n} \cap U=\{0\}$ and $S_{n} \subseteq U$. We will prove that each of these events is very likely, and thus, so is their conjunction, namely, $S_{n}=\{0\}$.

Probability of $S_{n} \cap U=\{0\}$
To prove that $S_{n} \cap U=\{0\}$ is very likely, we apply the induction hypothesis to the set $S^{\prime}:=S_{s} \cap U$ and the polynomial profile $\Psi^{\prime}:=\Psi_{s+1 \cdots n}$. Recall that $U$ is $S_{s}$-live, which implies $U$ is also $S^{\prime}$-live, therefore $U=\operatorname{Span}\left(S^{\prime} \cap U\right)=\operatorname{Span} S^{\prime}$ holds. Moreover $D_{U}<D_{W}$, so the induction hypothesis is indeed valid here.

Since $S$ is $k$-bounded, so is $S^{\prime}$. Similarly, $\operatorname{deg} \Psi^{\prime} \leq g$.
Let $V \subseteq U$ be $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear and $S^{\prime}$-live. Denote $D_{V}:=\operatorname{Dim} V$. Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Pi_{V}\left(S^{\prime}, \Psi^{\prime}\right) & =p_{V, s} \\
& \leq p_{V, s-1}+D_{V} \\
& \leq-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{V}+D_{V} \\
& =-\left(\lambda^{*}-1\right) \cdot D_{V}
\end{aligned}
$$

by the first part of Lemma 7.9

Also,

$$
\lambda^{*}-1 \geq \frac{\left(D_{W}-1\right) \cdot \lambda}{D_{W}} \geq 2 \cdot\left(D_{W}-1\right)\left(D_{W}+1\right) \geq 2 D_{U}\left(D_{U}+1\right)
$$

Hence, $\lambda^{*}-1$ satisfies Eqs. (34) and (35). The induction hypothesis thus yields

$$
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \cap U \supseteq\{0\} \mid F^{\prime}\right] \leq\left(2^{D_{U}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{U}} \cdot g \cdot n}{q\left(\lambda^{*}-1\right)}\right)^{\frac{\lambda^{*}-1}{2 D_{U}}}
$$

We turn to proving a lower bound on the probability of $S_{n} \subseteq U$. If $W$ is $S_{s}$-dead then $U=$ $\operatorname{Span} S_{s} \supseteq S_{n}$, so the event holds deterministically. We therefore proceed under the assumption that $W$ is $S_{s}$-live, and that $U$ is an $S_{s}$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear subspace satisfying $p_{U, s}>-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{U}$.

Our strategy is to use $\Psi$ to construct a new polynomial profile $\Psi^{\prime}$, such that applying the induction hypothesis to $\Psi^{\prime}$ implies that $S_{n} \subseteq U$ with high probability. For each entry $\psi_{i}$ in $\Psi$, the corresponding entry $\psi_{i}^{\prime}$ of $\Psi^{\prime}$ is a polynomial map chosen so that the following diagram commutes:

Here, $\pi$ is a polynomial map whose kernel is $U$, and the kernel of $\chi$ is $\psi(U)$. In order to apply the induction hypothesis to $\Psi^{\prime}$, we also need to control the degrees of the polynomial maps $\pi$ and $\psi^{\prime}$.
