Claim 7.11. Let $\mathbf{T} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{p \times e}(p \geq e)$ be a full-rank (over $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$ ) matrix of $d$-bounded polynomials $(d \in \mathbb{N})$. Then, there is a full-rank matrix $\mathbf{T}^{*} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{(p-e) \times p}$ of $(e \cdot d)$-bounded polynomials such that $\operatorname{ker} \mathbf{T}^{*}=\operatorname{Im} \mathbf{T}$.

Proof. Suppose without loss of generality that $\mathbf{T}$ can be written as a block matrix $\left[\begin{array}{c}\mathbf{T}_{1} \\ \mathbf{T}_{2}\end{array}\right]$ where $\mathbf{T}_{1} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{e \times e}$ has full-rank over $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$, and $\mathbf{T}_{2} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{(p-e) \times e}$.

Let $\mathbf{T}^{*} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{(p-e) \times p}$ be the block matrix $\operatorname{det}\left(\mathbf{T}_{1}\right) \cdot\left[-\mathbf{T}_{2} \mathbf{T}_{1}^{-1} \mid \mathbf{I}_{p-e}\right]$. Observe that $\operatorname{ker} \mathbf{T}^{*}=$ $\operatorname{Im} \mathbf{T}$. By Cramer's Rule, every entry of $\operatorname{det}\left(\mathbf{T}_{1}\right) \cdot \mathbf{T}_{1}^{-1}$ is a polynomial of degree at most $(e-1) \cdot d$. Thus, every entry of $\mathbf{T}^{*}$ is a polynomial of degree at most $e \cdot d$.

Claim 7.12. There exists an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear polynomial map $\pi: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b-D_{U}}$ with $\operatorname{ker} \pi=$ $U$ and $\operatorname{deg} \pi \leq D_{U} \cdot k$.

Proof. Since $U$ is $S_{s}$-live, there is a matrix $\mathbf{T} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b \times D_{U}}$ such that $\operatorname{Im} \mathbf{T}=U$ and the columns of $\mathbf{T}$ belong to $S_{s}$. In particular, because $S_{s}$ is a $k$-bounded space, every entry of $\mathbf{T}$ is a polynomial in $\mathbb{F}_{q}[X]$ of degree at most $k$. Therefore, $\mathbf{T}$ satisfies the conditions of Claim 7.11 with $p=b, e=D_{U}$, and $d=k$. Let $\mathbf{T}^{*}$ be the matrix guaranteed by Claim 7.11. Take $\pi$ to be the $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear map that $\mathbf{T}^{*}$ represents in the standard basis. The claim follows immediately.

Claim 7.13. Let $\pi$ be as in Claim 7.12 and let $\psi: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a}(a \leq b)$ be an $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$ linear polynomial map of degree $d$ and rank a. Then, there exist $r \in \mathbb{N}$ and $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear maps $\psi^{\prime}: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b-d_{U}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{r}$ and $\chi: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{r}$ with the following properties:

- $\chi \circ \psi=\psi^{\prime} \circ \pi$.
- $\psi^{\prime}$ is a polynomial map of degree at most $\max \left\{b \cdot d, b \cdot D_{U} \cdot k\right\}$
- $\operatorname{ker} \chi=\psi(U)$

Proof. In this proof, all dimensions and ranks are with regard to the field $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$. Let $\mathbf{M}_{\pi} \in$ $\mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{\left(b-D_{U}\right) \times b}$ and $\mathbf{M}_{\psi} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{a \times b}$ be full-rank matrices representing $\pi$ and $\psi$ in the standard basis, respectively. By Claim 7.12 we know that every entry in $\mathbf{M}_{\pi}$ is a polynomial having degree at most $D_{U} \cdot k$. By hypothesis, we assume that every entry in $\mathbf{M}_{\psi}$ is a polynomial having degree at most $d$. By a slight abuse of notation, we will use $\operatorname{Span}(\mathbf{M})$ to denote the $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-span of the columns of some matrix $\mathbf{M}$.

Let

$$
\begin{aligned}
r & :=\operatorname{Dim}\left(\operatorname{Span}\left(\mathbf{M}_{\psi}^{\top}\right) \cap \operatorname{Span}\left(\mathbf{M}_{\pi}^{\top}\right)\right) \\
& =b-\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \psi+\operatorname{ker} \pi) \\
& =b-\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \psi)-\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \pi)+\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \psi \cap \operatorname{ker} \pi) \\
& =a-(\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \pi)+\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \psi \cap \operatorname{ker} \pi))=a-(\operatorname{Dim}(U)-\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \psi \cap U)) \\
& =a-\operatorname{Dim}(\psi(U))
\end{aligned}
$$

The first equality follows by the rank-nullity theorem and De-Morgan's law. Let $\mathbf{Z} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{\left(b-D_{U}+a\right) \times b}$ denote the block matrix $\left[\frac{\mathbf{M}_{\pi}}{\mathbf{M}_{\psi}}\right]$. Define $e:=b-D_{U}+a-r \leq b$ and note that Rank $\mathbf{Z}=e$. Let $\mathbf{T} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{\left(b-D_{U}+a\right) \times e}$ be a submatrix of $\mathbf{Z}$ obtained by selecting a set of $e$ columns so that Rank $\mathbf{T}=e$. Let $\mathbf{T}^{*} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{r \times\left(b-D_{U}+a\right)}$ be the matrix guaranteed by Claim 7.11, corresponding to T. In particular, $\operatorname{ker} \mathbf{T}^{*}=\operatorname{Span}(\mathbf{T})=\operatorname{Span}(\mathbf{Z})$.

Write $\mathbf{T}^{*}$ as a block matrix $\left[\mathbf{P} \mid \mathbf{Q}\right]$ where $\mathbf{P} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{r \times\left(b-D_{U}\right)}$ and $\mathbf{Q} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{r \times a}$. We take $\psi^{\prime}$ and $\chi$ to be the $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear maps represented by $\mathbf{P}$ and $-\mathbf{Q}$, respectively. We turn to show that $\psi^{\prime}$ and $\chi$ satisfy the required properties.

The first property is equivalent to $-\mathbf{Q} \mathbf{M}_{\psi}=\mathbf{P} \mathbf{M}_{\pi}$. This is true since $\mathbf{T}^{*} \mathbf{T}=0$, thus, implying $\mathbf{T}^{*} \mathbf{Z}=0$. Therefore,

$$
0=\mathbf{T}^{*} \mathbf{Z}=\mathbf{P} \mathbf{M}_{\pi}+\mathbf{Q} \mathbf{M}_{\psi}
$$

For the second condition, Claim 7.11 guarantees that each entry of $\mathbf{T}^{*}$, and thus also of $\mathbf{P}$, has degree at most $\max \left\{d, D_{U} \cdot k\right\} \cdot e \leq \max \left\{b \cdot d, b \cdot D_{U} \cdot k\right\}$.

For the third condition, let $u \in U$, and recall that $U=\operatorname{ker} \pi$. Then,

$$
0=\mathbf{T}^{*} \mathbf{Z} u=\mathbf{P M}_{\pi} u+\mathbf{Q} \mathbf{M}_{\psi} u=\psi^{\prime}(\pi(u))+\chi(\psi(u))=\chi(\psi(u))
$$

where $\psi^{\prime}(\pi(u))=0$ as $u \in \operatorname{ker} \pi$, so $\psi(U) \subseteq \operatorname{ker} \chi$. On the other hand, suppose that $x \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a}$ such that $\chi(x)=0$. Let $y:=\mathbf{0}_{b-D_{U}} \circ x$ denote the concatenation of $b-D_{U}$ zeros and $x$. Then, $\mathbf{T}^{*} y=\mathbf{Q} x=\chi(x)=0$, so $y \in \operatorname{ker} \mathbf{T}^{*}=\operatorname{Im} \mathbf{Z}$. Let $w \in \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b}$ be such that $\mathbf{Z} w=y$. Then, $\pi(w)=$ $\mathbf{M}_{\pi} w=0$ and $\psi(w)=\mathbf{M}_{\psi} w=x$ hold by the definition of $y$. This implies that $w \in \operatorname{ker} \pi=U$ and $x \in \psi(U)$.

Claim 7.14. Let $\chi: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{r}$ be a polynomial map. Let $\alpha \in \mathbb{F}_{q}$ and $p \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]^{b}$ be such that $p(\alpha)=0$. Then, $\chi(p)(\alpha)=0$.

Proof. It suffices to prove the claim for $r=1$. Write $\chi(p)=\sum_{i=1}^{a} q_{i} p_{i}$ where $q_{i} \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]$ for each $i$. Then,

$$
\chi(p)(\alpha)=\sum_{i=1}^{a} q_{i}(\alpha) \cdot p_{i}(\alpha)=\sum_{i=1}^{a} q_{i}(\alpha) \cdot 0=0
$$

To lower bound the probability of $S_{n} \subseteq U$ we apply the induction hypothesis to a space of polynomials and a polynomial profile that we now construct. Let $\pi$ be as in Claim 7.12 and let $S^{\prime}=\pi\left(S_{s}\right)$. Recall that $\Psi$ is a $b$-local polynomial profile, therefore for every $i$ such that $s+1 \leq i \leq n$, we have a polynomial map $\psi_{i}: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a_{i}}$, for some $0 \leq a_{i} \leq b$. By applying Claim 7.13 for $\pi$ and every $\psi_{i}$ for $s+1 \leq i \leq n$, we see that there exists an $r_{i}$ and $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear maps $\psi_{i}^{\prime}: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{b-D_{U}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{r_{i}}$ and $\chi_{i}: \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{a_{i}} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}_{q}(X)^{r_{i}}$. Let $\Psi^{\prime}=\left(\psi_{s+1}^{\prime}, \ldots, \psi_{n}^{\prime}\right)$. Let $\boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}=\boldsymbol{\alpha}_{s+1 \cdots n}$.

We claim that

$$
S^{\prime}\left[\Psi^{\prime}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]=\{0\} \quad \Longrightarrow \quad S_{n} \subseteq U
$$

Indeed, suppose that $S^{\prime}\left[\Psi^{\prime}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]=\{0\}$ and let $p \in S_{n}$. We need to show that $p \in U$. Let $p^{\prime}=\pi(p)$ and let $i$ be such that $s+1 \leq i \leq n$. Since $p \in S_{n}$, we have $\psi_{i}(p)\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=0$. Therefore,

$$
\psi_{i}^{\prime}\left(p^{\prime}\right)\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=\left(\left(\psi_{i}^{\prime} \circ \pi\right)(p)\right)\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=\left(\left(\chi_{i} \circ \psi_{i}\right)(p)\right)\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=\chi_{i}\left(\psi_{i}(p)\right)\left(\alpha_{i}\right)=0
$$

Where the last equality is due to Claim 7.14. Therefore, $p^{\prime} \in S^{\prime}\left[\Psi^{\prime}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}\right]$, whence $\pi(p)=p^{\prime}=0$. Thus, $p \in \operatorname{ker} \pi=U$.

Applying the induction hypothesis: Observe that because $W$ is $S_{s}$-live and $S_{s} \subseteq S \subseteq$ $W$, $\operatorname{Span} S_{s}=W$ holds. Therefore $\operatorname{Span} S^{\prime}=\operatorname{Span} \pi\left(S_{s}\right)=\pi\left(\operatorname{Span} S_{s}\right)=\pi(W)$. Recall that $\operatorname{Dim} U \geq 1$, let $W^{\prime}:=\operatorname{Span} S^{\prime}=\pi(W)$ and note that $\operatorname{Dim} W^{\prime}=\operatorname{Dim} W-\operatorname{Dim}(\operatorname{ker} \pi \cap W)=$ $\operatorname{Dim} W-\operatorname{Dim} U<\operatorname{Dim} W$. We will now apply the induction hypothesis to $S^{\prime}, \Psi^{\prime}$ and $W^{\prime}$, after showing that they satisfy the required conditions. First, note that $W^{\prime}$ satisfies $W^{\prime}=\operatorname{Span} S^{\prime}$ by definition, and we just showed that $\operatorname{Dim} W^{\prime}<\operatorname{Dim} W$.

We now prove that for every $S^{\prime}$-live $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear space $V^{\prime} \subseteq W^{\prime}$, the following holds

$$
\Pi_{V^{\prime}}\left(S^{\prime}, \Psi^{\prime}\right) \leq-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{V^{\prime}}
$$

This is easily seen to be true when $V^{\prime}$ is the zero subspace, hence assume that it is not. Let $U^{\prime}=\pi^{-1}\left(V^{\prime}\right)$ and note that $U \subset U^{\prime} \subseteq W$. We now prove the following claim:

Claim 7.15. Let $S_{s}, S^{\prime}, V^{\prime}, U^{\prime}$ be as defined above. The following holds:

$$
\pi\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)=\pi\left(S_{s}\right) \cap \pi\left(U^{\prime}\right)=S^{\prime} \cap V^{\prime}
$$

Proof. The second equality is true by definitions of $S^{\prime}, U^{\prime}$, so we prove the first equality. The containment $\pi\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right) \subseteq \pi\left(S_{s}\right) \cap \pi\left(U^{\prime}\right)$ is easy to see. The other containment is proved as follows: fix a $p \in \pi\left(S_{s}\right) \cap \pi\left(U^{\prime}\right)$. Because $p \in S^{\prime}$, there is a $q \in S_{s}$ so that $p=\pi(q)$. Now $q$ must also be in $U^{\prime}$, because if not, then $\pi(q) \notin V^{\prime}$ by the definition of $U^{\prime}$, which would contradict the fact that $\pi(q)=p \in V^{\prime}$.

Combining Claim 7.15 and the following two equations:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\operatorname{ker} \pi \cap\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)=U \cap S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}=U \cap S_{s} \\
\operatorname{dim}\left(\pi\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)\right)=\operatorname{dim}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(\operatorname{ker} \pi \cap\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)\right)
\end{gathered}
$$

we see that the following is true

$$
\operatorname{dim}\left(S^{\prime} \cap V^{\prime}\right)=\operatorname{dim}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap S_{s}\right)
$$

Observe that we have used dim (and not Dim) in the previous sentence. Because the spaces and maps we are considering are $\mathbb{F}_{q}$-linear (in fact, they are $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linear) subspaces and maps respectively, we can apply rank-nullity theorem while viewing them as linear over the field $\mathbb{F}_{q}$.

Note that for $s+1 \leq i \leq n$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{i}^{\prime}\left(V^{\prime}\right)\right) & =\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{i}^{\prime} \circ \pi\left(U^{\prime}\right)\right)\left)=\operatorname{Dim}\left(\chi_{i} \circ \psi_{i}\left(U^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{i}\left(U^{\prime}\right)\right)-\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{i}\left(U^{\prime}\right) \cap \operatorname{ker} \chi_{i}\right)=\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{i}\left(U^{\prime}\right)\right)-\operatorname{Dim}\left(\psi_{i}(U)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the fact that $\operatorname{ker} \chi_{i}=\psi_{i}(U)$ for the last equality. Now, by Eq. (42) and Eq. (43) we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Pi_{V^{\prime}}\left(S^{\prime}, \Psi^{\prime}\right) & =\operatorname{dim}\left(S^{\prime} \cap V^{\prime}\right)-\operatorname{strength}_{V^{\prime}}\left(\Psi^{\prime}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{dim}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)-\operatorname{dim}\left(U \cap S_{s}\right)-\operatorname{strength}_{U^{\prime}}\left(\Psi_{s+1 \cdots n}\right)+\operatorname{strength}_{U}\left(\Psi_{s+1 \cdots n}\right) \\
& =p_{U^{\prime}, s}-p_{U, s}
\end{aligned}
$$

We will now prove

$$
p_{U^{\prime}, s} \leq-\lambda^{*} D_{U^{\prime}}
$$

Observe that because $U$ is an inclusion-maximal $S_{s}$-live subspace such that $p_{U, s}>-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{U}$, it is suffices to prove that $U^{\prime}$ is $S_{s}$-live. Note that $\operatorname{Span}\left(S^{\prime} \cap V^{\prime}\right)=V^{\prime}$ because $V^{\prime}$ is $S^{\prime}$-live, and by Claim 7.15 and $\mathbb{F}_{q}(X)$-linearity of $\pi$, we see that

$$
V^{\prime}=\operatorname{Span}\left(S^{\prime} \cap V^{\prime}\right)=\operatorname{Span}\left(\pi\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)\right)=\pi\left(\operatorname{Span}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)\right)
$$

Because $U$ is $S_{s}$-live, $\operatorname{Span}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)$ contains $\operatorname{ker} \pi=U$ and therefore we have that $\pi^{-1}\left(\pi\left(\operatorname{Span}\left(S_{s} \cap\right.\right.\right.$ $\left.\left.U^{\prime}\right)\right)\left)=\operatorname{Span}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)$. This together with Eq. (44) implies $\operatorname{Span}\left(S_{s} \cap U^{\prime}\right)=\pi^{-1}\left(V^{\prime}\right)=U^{\prime}$, and so $U^{\prime}$ is $S_{s}$-live.

Therefore,

$$
\Pi_{V^{\prime}}\left(S^{\prime}, \Psi^{\prime}\right) \leq-\lambda^{*}\left(D_{U^{\prime}}-D_{U}\right)=-\lambda^{*} \cdot D_{V^{\prime}}
$$

The last equality holds by the rank-nullity theorem applied on the subspace $U^{\prime}$ and map $\pi$. By Eq. (34) applied to $\lambda$, and Eq. (36),

$$
\lambda^{*} \geq \frac{\left(D_{W}-1\right) \cdot \lambda}{D_{W}} \geq \frac{2 D_{W}\left(D_{W}+1\right)\left(D_{W}-1\right)}{D_{W}}=2\left(D_{W}+1\right)\left(D_{W}-1\right) \geq 2\left(D_{W^{\prime}}+1\right) \cdot D_{W^{\prime}}
$$

so $\lambda^{*}$ satisfies Eq. (34) with regard to $D_{W^{\prime}}$. Recall that $g$ was equal to $\max (\operatorname{deg} \Psi, b \cdot k)$, and set $k^{\prime}:=b \cdot D_{U} \cdot k$ and $g^{\prime}:=b^{2} g$. By Claim 7.11 and Claim 7.12, $S^{\prime}$ is $k^{\prime}$-bounded. By Claim 7.13,

$$
\operatorname{deg} \Psi^{\prime} \leq \max \left\{b \cdot \operatorname{deg} \Psi, b \cdot D_{U} \cdot k\right\} \leq b g
$$

Note that $g^{\prime} \geq \max \left\{\operatorname{deg} \Psi^{\prime}, b \cdot k^{\prime}\right\}$. We have now proven that $S^{\prime}, \Psi^{\prime}$, and $W^{\prime}$ indeed satisfy the required conditions, with $g^{\prime}, \lambda^{*}$ being the new value for $g, \lambda$ respectively, and therefore by Eq. (40),

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \not \subseteq U \mid F^{\prime}\right] & \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S^{\prime}\left[\Psi^{\prime}, \boldsymbol{\alpha}^{\prime}\right] \supseteq\{0\} \mid F^{\prime}\right] \\
& \leq\left(2^{D_{W^{\prime}}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W^{\prime}}} \cdot g^{\prime} \cdot(n-s)}{q \cdot \lambda^{*}}\right)^{\frac{\lambda^{*}}{2 D_{W^{\prime}}}} \\
& =\left(2^{D_{W^{\prime}}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W^{\prime}}} \cdot b^{2} \cdot g \cdot(n-s)}{q \cdot \lambda^{*}}\right)^{\frac{\lambda^{*}}{2 D_{W^{\prime}}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Putting it All Together - Probability of $S_{n}=\{0\}$
Recall that because $U \subsetneq W$ and because $U$ is a non-trivial subspace, $D_{W}>1$ holds. Eqs. (39) and (45) yield

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \neq\{0\} \mid F^{\prime}\right] \leq & \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \cap U \neq\{0\} \mid F^{\prime}\right]+ \\
& \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \nsubseteq U \mid F^{\prime}\right] \\
\leq & \left(2^{D_{U}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{U}} \cdot g \cdot n}{q\left(\lambda^{*}-1\right)}\right)^{\frac{\lambda^{*}-1}{2 D_{U}}} \\
& \left(2^{D_{W^{\prime}}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2\left(D_{W^{\prime}}+1\right)} \cdot g \cdot(n-s)}{q \cdot \lambda^{*}}\right)^{\frac{\lambda^{*}}{2 D_{W^{\prime}}}} \\
\leq & \left(2^{D_{W}}-2\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W}} \cdot g \cdot n}{q\left(\lambda^{*}-1\right)}\right)^{\frac{\lambda^{*}-1}{2 D_{W}}} \\
\leq & \left(2^{D_{W}}-2\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W}} \cdot g \cdot n}{q \cdot \lambda}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The second last inequality is true because $D_{W^{\prime}}<D_{W}, D_{U}<D_{W}$ are true, and the last inequality is true by Eq. (36).

Recall that Eq. (38) yields an upper bound on $\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\overline{F^{\prime}}\right]$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \neq\{0\}\right] & \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\overline{F^{\prime}} \wedge S_{n} \neq\{0\}\right]+\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \neq\{0\} \wedge F^{\prime}\right] \\
& \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\overline{F^{\prime}}\right]+\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[F^{\prime}\right] \cdot \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \neq\{0\} \mid F^{\prime}\right] \\
& \leq \operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[\overline{F^{\prime}}\right]+\operatorname{Pr}_{\boldsymbol{\alpha}}\left[S_{n} \neq\{0\} \mid F^{\prime}\right] \\
& \leq\left(\frac{4 e \cdot D_{W}^{2} \cdot g \cdot n}{q \cdot \lambda}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}}+\left(2^{D_{W}}-2\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W}} \cdot g \cdot n}{q \cdot \lambda}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}} \\
& \leq\left(2^{D_{W}}-1\right) \cdot\left(\frac{4 e \cdot b^{2 D_{W}} \cdot g \cdot n}{q \cdot \lambda}\right)^{\frac{\lambda}{2 D_{W}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

which yields the lemma.

# A Random Code Models
## A. 1 Models of Random Linear Codes

In this work, a random linear code of rate $R$ is the kernel $\mathcal{C}$ of a uniformly random matrix $P \in$ $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{(n-k) \times n}$. We note that if $P$ happens not to have full rank, the code $\mathcal{C}$ would have rate larger than $R$. An arguably more accurate way to interpret the notion of random linear code is to sample a code $\mathcal{C}^{\prime}$ uniformly at random from among all linear subspace of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ of dimension $R n$. However, the former model is usually nicer to work with because it satisfies the elegant Lemma 4.1. We justify our use of the former model rather than the latter by the following observation.

Lemma A.1. Write $k=R n$. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be the kernel of a uniformly random matrix $P \in \mathbb{F}_{q}^{(n-k) \times n}$. Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a uniformly random subspace of $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ of dimension $k$. Then, the statistical difference between $\mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{C}^{\prime}$ is at most $1-e^{-q^{-R n} \cdot n}$.

Proof. It is a well known fact that $P$ has full rank with probability

$$
\prod_{i=k+1}^{n}\left(1-q^{-i}\right) \geq\left(1-q^{-k}\right)^{n} \geq e^{-q^{-R n} \cdot n}
$$

The lemma follows since, conditioned on $P$ having full rank, $\mathcal{C}$ and $\mathcal{C}^{\prime}$ have the same distribution.

## A. 2 Models of Random RS Codes

For us, a random RS code is a code $\mathcal{C}=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\left(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}\right) ; k\right)$ where $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ are sampled independently and uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}$. Consider now the random code $\mathcal{C}^{\prime}=\mathrm{RS}_{\mathbb{F}_{q}}\left(\left(\beta_{1}, \ldots, \beta_{n}\right) ; k\right)$ where $\beta_{1}, \ldots, \beta_{n}$ are sampled uniformly from $\mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ without repetitions. While we have chosen to work with the former model out of convenience, we show that our results about list-decodability and list-recoverability essentially apply to the latter model as well. In fact, any result about the geometry of $\mathcal{C}$ also holds approximately for $\mathcal{C}^{\prime}$. This is due to the following lemma, which gives a coupling between the two models such that there exists an approximately distance preserving map between the two, provided that $\frac{n}{q}$ is small enough.
Lemma A.2. Write $k=R n$. Then, exists a coupling $\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{C}^{\prime}\right)$ where $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ is a random $R S$ code of dimension $k$ and $\mathcal{C}^{\prime} \subseteq \mathbb{F}_{q}^{n}$ is a random $R S$ code of dimension $k$ without repetitions, such that there exists a linear bijection $\varphi: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\prime}$ with

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left[\max _{x \in \mathcal{C}}\{\operatorname{wt}(x-\varphi(x))\} \geq n-q\left(1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}\right) \cdot(1-\delta)\right] \leq\left(\frac{e^{-\delta}}{(1-\delta)^{1-\delta}}\right)^{q\left(1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}\right)}
$$

for all $0<\delta<1$.
Proof. Sample $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n}$ uniformly and independently at random from $\mathbb{F}_{q}$. Let

$$
I=\left\{i \in[n] \mid \exists j<i \quad \alpha_{i}=\alpha_{j}\right\}
$$

Sample $\beta_{1}, \ldots, \beta_{n}$ as follows: For each $i \in[n] \backslash I$, take $\beta_{i}=\alpha_{i}$. Then, sample $\beta_{i}$ for all $i \in I$ to complete the sequence in a uniform repetition-less manner.

Let $\varphi: \mathcal{C} \rightarrow \mathcal{C}^{\prime}$ map $\left(Q\left(\alpha_{1}\right), \ldots, Q\left(\alpha_{n}\right)\right)$ to $\left(Q\left(\beta_{1}\right), \ldots, Q\left(\beta_{n}\right)\right)$ for every $Q \in \mathbb{F}_{q}[X]$ with $\operatorname{deg} Q \leq k$. Clearly, $\operatorname{wt}(x-\varphi(x)) \leq|I|$ for each $x \in \mathcal{C}$. Hence, to prove the lemma it suffices to give a probabilistic upper bound on $|I|$.

Consider a balls and bin scenario in which $n$ balls are each thrown into one of $q$ bins with uniform probability. Let $X$ denote the number of non-empty bins. Note that $|I|$ is distributed identically to $n-X$. Let $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{q}$ be variables such that $X_{i}$ takes 1 if the $i$-th bin is full, and 0 if it is empty. Note that $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{i}\right]=1-\left(1-\frac{1}{q}\right)^{n} \geq 1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}$, so $\mathbb{E}[X] \geq q \cdot\left(1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}\right)$.

Observe that $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{q}$ are in negative association (see [Waj17]). Indeed, by [Waj17, Theorem 10], the occupancy numbers, indicating the number of balls in each bin, are in negative association. Since $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{q}$ are monotone-increasing functions of the occupancy numbers, the relevant closure property [Waj17, Lemma 9], implies that $X_{1}, \ldots, X_{q}$ are also negatively associated. Thus, a Chernoff-Hoeffding bound [Waj17, Theorem 5] applies to their sum. Thus,

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left[|I| \geq n-q\left(1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}\right) \cdot(1-\delta)\right]=\operatorname{Pr}\left[X \leq q\left(1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}\right) \cdot(1-\delta)\right] \leq\left(\frac{e^{-\delta}}{(1-\delta)^{1-\delta}}\right)^{q\left(1-e^{-\frac{n}{q}}\right)}
$$

We establish an equivalence between two important random ensembles of linear
codes: random linear codes (RLCs) and random Reed-Solomon (RS) codes.
Specifically, we show that these models exhibit identical behavior with respect
to key combinatorial properties -- such as list-decodability and
list-recoverability -- when the alphabet size is sufficiently large.
  We introduce monotone-decreasing local coordinate-wise linear (LCL)
properties, a new class of properties tailored for the large alphabet regime.
This class encompasses list-decodability, list-recoverability, and their
average-weight variants. We develop a framework for analyzing these properties
and prove a threshold theorem for RLCs: for any LCL property ${P}$, there
exists a threshold rate $R_{P}$ such that RLCs are likely to satisfy ${P}$ when
$R < R_{P}$ and unlikely to do so when $R > R_{P}$. We extend this threshold
theorem to random RS codes and show that they share the same threshold $ R_{P}
$, thereby establishing the equivalence between the two ensembles and enabling
a unified analysis of list-recoverability and related properties.
  Applying our framework, we compute the threshold rate for list-decodability,
proving that both random RS codes and RLCs achieve the generalized Singleton
bound. This recovers a recent result of Alrabiah, Guruswami, and Li (2023) via
elementary methods. Additionally, we prove an upper bound on the
list-recoverability threshold and conjecture that this bound is tight.
  Our approach suggests a plausible pathway for proving this conjecture and
thereby pinpointing the list-recoverability parameters of both models. Indeed,
following the release of a prior version of this paper, Li and Shagrithaya
(2025) used our equivalence theorem to show that random RS codes are
near-optimally list-recoverable.
